name: Just You and Me
description:
An album dedicated purely to the acoustically rich and rewarding sound of the veena, a stringed instrument of ancient South Indian history and lore.

Featuring a range of ragas, starting from morning prayerful melodies of Bowli, the straight forward Gowla, on to the unique and awe inspiring dignity of the raga Todi, winding on to the flavor of an Indian afternoon in the monsoon with a rhythmic free flowing exposition of the raga Kirvani, and then over to the beauty and charm of the alluring Karaharapriya, on to the laidback Purvikalyani and a lullaby to end it all.

Some of these are interpretations of classical gems, others are extempore free flowing explorations into the form and characteristics of the raga. A traditional musical offering of pure South Indian Carnatic classical music, from the artist and the instrument, to God.

Imagine Indian temples, religious festivals, spiritual quests, contemplation, introspection and the soul's awakening.

name: Lava Lounge
description:
Stylishly contemplative with a twist of red hot active lava on top! That's the sound of this album. I wanted to reflect on the two constant movements within oneself, one inwards and the other outwards. I have attempted to capture the spirit of those subtle movements in this album.

With Coral Symphony, Sunbrella, Blue Petal Lake and Turquoise Beat, it's the introspective, looking within movement, then on towards an outward swing with Star Filter, French Lounge, Purplesse Oblige, Lava Lounge, Riviera Magenta and ending with a very socially interactive Cocktail Disco. Musical portrait of the self!

name: Trip Along
description:
Sophisticated electronica with sultry vocals; female, male and a choir, eclectic in its choice of languages, from English to French via Latin connected with ancient Indian poems (known as cheez in Hindustani classical music) and the hoary Dravidian tongue of Tamil, electronically filtered samples; this album explores musical textures from every angle and language!

The ambiance also shifts in a pleasant kaleidoscopic array, from a happy monsoon welcoming song, to seductive love songs sung to a lover, some also to God, to metaphysical and linguistic contemplation on silence and words, to the grand Latin phrase "Veritas Vos Liberabit"!

Step into a luxurious resort tucked away under the green fronds in a magical forest, or far out on in deep space, high above the clouds and the mist of a moonlit night, or simply deep inside the recesses of your heart and find yourself wafting peacefully into your zen lounge where you are always welcome! So, trip along!

name: Chameleon
description:
"The hidden secret in this music is balm to the soul" writes one of many UK therapists who use the album as an aid to relaxation and meditation. Some of the music on the album was used in a pilot study at Bristol Cancer Help Centre, UK, and results showed listeners experiencing an increased sense of well-being and relaxation and a significant drop in tension. A physiological test also showed significantly increased levels of salivary IgA (which is an indicator of immune status) and measured decreased levels of cortisol (a stress indicator), marking relaxation and improved mood.

Comments from patients included the following:
"The power of the music uplifted the spirit"
"I felt totally at peace"
"Music to feed the soul and fortify the body"
"The power of the music to disarm and enter people, to lift up their spirits and make them whole is amazing."

Try it!

name: The Vision Of Enoch
description:
This is an extraordinary meditative piece, and was recorded in Douai Abbey in the UK. This piece is a setting of inspirational words translated from the Gospel of the Essenes by Edmond Bordeaux Szekely and is gloriously sung by the acclaimed counter-tenor Robin Blaze and soprano Jackie Evill, accompanied only by three pitched singing bowls.

The words are reproduced by kind permission of the International Biogenic Society, Nelson, British Columbia, Canada and are available when you download the artwork.

name: Sitting on the windowsill of Heaven - Celia Harper
description: Sulis encourages the listener to be embraced by the sounds of its unusual instruments and haunting melodies, creating a musical space for personal reflection. Tuneful and touching music with influences of early baroque and Celtic.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Sulis/Sitting on the windowsill of Heaven - Celia Harper/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Sulis/Sitting on the windowsill of Heaven - Celia Harper/cover_200.jpg

name: Into Heaven
description: After releasing Sun Palace's latest album in December 2005, we were lucky enough to get our hands on this band's year 2000 debut CD?Into Heaven?which received four out of five stars from AllMusic.com and shows the more wistful, contemplative side of vocalist Andriette Redmann's talents. Written and recorded after a series of personal tragedies in her life, Into Heaven's palpable sense of melancholy serves as the ideal counterpoint to Redmann's lighter-than-air voice, and we suspect that fans of Sarah McLachlan and The Sundays will love this album.

name: Give Me a Perfect World
description: Angel-voiced Andriette Redmann teams up with Smithereens frontman John Rokosny to make a luxuriant yet lighter than air pop-rock creation. Give Me A Perfect World does more than live up to the promise of the first Sun Palace album, Into Heaven?it is, in fact, an even stronger and more impressive demonstration of Redmann's talents. Highlights include the idyllic title track, the courtly and fateful "Round and Round," as well as the deeply dreamy "Familiar Voices." This album features legendary drummer Jerry Marotta (Peter Gabriel/Paul McCartney/Elvis Costello) and cellist Jane Scarpantoni (Springsteen/Lou Reed/REM). Highly expressive, highly listenable.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Sun Palace/Give Me a Perfect World/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Sun Palace/Give Me a Perfect World/cover_200.jpg

name: Sundowner
description: Straight out of Manchester, a startlingly fantastic first album from Sundowner who have an expertly trippy, drone heavy sound. Relentless walls of sonic heaviness somehow transmogrify into ethereal bliss with vocals that just absolutely _fly_. on tracks like "High on Strife" and "The Morning Won't Wait." One of the most superlative rock offerings we've ever made on Magnatune. Check it out.

name: The Afro Dub EP
description: The Afro-Dub EP collects the band's first two 45 inch vinyl releases on Electric Cowbell Records, plus some bonus tracks and remixes. Released in 2012, the "Single Payer" single features the band's original plus a three-part re-imagining of the track by dub and ska legend Victor Rice. "We Will Begin Again," also released in 2012, adds a dub version by Brooklyn dub engineer Prince Polo and a hallucinogenic remix by DJ Trainwreck (bassist Ezra Gale's alter ego). Finally, a dub version of the unreleased "March of the Frogs" by Oakland, CA producer Myles Boisin rounds out the EP.

name: Algoriddims
description:
This album is a sound explosion! Inspired by classical harmonies and beats that groove to hell, Superdirt2 (Ras Tilo (electro, programming) and Kapt'n Dirt (cello) recorded their first full-length album.

The album is a synergism of what they believe music ought to be: nine tracks consumed by a deep emotional feeling, completed by an ecstatic and overwhelming groove character. All of this is conveyed through their compulsive need to share their passion of music to everyone who is ready to celebrate the party, which is called life.

name: Among the Lasses, songs of Robert Burns (1759-1796)
description:
Soprano Susan Rode Morris and harpsichordist Phebe Craig offer a look at one way Burns heard his songs played. Among the Lasses is the second in the trio collection of the beloved songs of Scotland's national poet Robert Burns.

They have gone back to the original tunes and have created their own bass lines and arrangements based on their knowledge of 18th century music. The poetry and tunes are delightful and refreshing. Burns was not a composer, but a great collector of his national music. He took existing songs that were only partly remembered and rewrote the verses to "mend them" as he wrote. He set his poetry to his favorite fiddle or bagpipe tunes.

Reviews include American Record Guide's comments: "Morris sings with wonderful abandon, never losing control of tone or intonation. She has a lovely lilting voice, sometimes changing her tome quality to a surprising degree as she finds the right timbre for a special moment." "Morris and Craig approach the world of 18th century music making in a most profound way."
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Susan Rode Morris/Among the Lasses, songs of Robert Burns (1759-1796)/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Susan Rode Morris/Among the Lasses, songs of Robert Burns (1759-1796)/cover_200.jpg

name: Between Late and Early - Romantic Songs of Robert Burns (1759-1796)
description:
When singer Susan Rode Morris and harpsichordist Phebe Craig met and performed with renowned Scottish fiddle Alasdair Fraser, they discovered the songs of Robert Burns, Scotland's National Poet.

Few people know that Burns collected his native tunes and songs and created poetry to many of the wonderful fiddle tunes he loved.

Featured on National Public Radio on Robert Burns birthday, this album includes the original version of Auld Lang Syne, which has been played on public radio on New Year's Eve. "This wonderful performance engendered more response that just about any recording we can remember, in this or any other year" said Martin Goldsmith of Performance Today of NPR. "Hauntingly beautiful renditions, skilled, loving, exquisite."
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Susan Rode Morris/Between Late and Early - Romantic Songs of Robert Burns (1759-1796)/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Susan Rode Morris/Between Late and Early - Romantic Songs of Robert Burns (1759-1796)/cover_200.jpg

name: Ohhh Henry! - Songs of Henry Purcell
description:
Henry Purcell was one of England's greatest song writers of the 17th century. This recording is a veritable potpourri for the listener with two dozen songs, some rarely recorded, offering a wide range of expression.

Reviews have praised this recording for its beauty:

"Seldom have these songs of Purcell been given such thoughtful renditions by both singer and harpsichordist...a gorgeous voice, extraordinary continuo playing." American Record Guide.

"If you love beautiful soprano voices, communicative singing or great Purcell songs, I recommend this disc." Fanfare Magazine.

"Ohhh Henry! joyfully transcends... Of the three new soprano collections Morris has the richest imagination in both the selection and interpretation of the music." Washington Post
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Susan Rode Morris/Ohhh Henry! - Songs of Henry Purcell/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Susan Rode Morris/Ohhh Henry! - Songs of Henry Purcell/cover_200.jpg

name: Enchanted Wind
description: We think Enchanted Wind is global flutist Suzanne Teng's best yet: seven long tracks that showcase her sinuous, slowly unfolding melodies on the alto flute, bass flute, and the rare contrabass flute. The mood here is profoundly quiet and serene; there are no beats at all and the accompaniment on harp, dulcimer, harmonium, and zither is delicate and minimal. The approach shows the full scope of Teng's talent too; stripped of adornment, you really hear how masterful her tone and breath control are, and the music itself is timeless. Listen after a stressful day and marvel, as we did, at how completely it dissolves tension.

name: Miles Beyond
description: The Chinese define "chi" as the circulating life energy inherent in all things, and on Miles Beyond, best-selling Magnatune artist Suzanne Teng's music is absolutely suffused with it. Serene and mysterious, yet also possessing a subtly lively, spirited quality, this album features her gorgeous contemporary instrumental pieces-soundscapes with exquisitely close wooden flute harmonies, fantastic tribal percussion, thoughtful strings and an overall feeling of well being. "A meticulously composed and arranged work that uses traditional sounds for a new pan-global music." -John Diliberto, Public Radio International

name: Mystic Journey
description: A lithe, fluid, and graceful album of Suzanne Teng's exquisite pan-global instrumental music, Mystic Journey really delivers the goods with its fantastic performance by Suzanne Teng and her band, as well as its great production values. Teng plays with masterful ease, and it's easy to detect her joy in the performance of these beautiful east-meets-west compositions. Al Martinez of the L.A. Times says: "Suzanne Teng plays music for the soul. This music will stay with me for a lifetime."

name: Svanevit
description: John writes: Magnatune musician Tim Rayborn introduced me to his Swedish Folk musician friend Erik Ask-Upmark. They've played together many times (most recently when Erik was on tour, and passed through San Francisco). Erik has many projects, all focussed on traditional Swedish folk music, so be sure to check out his solo album, his album with Anna Rynefors entitled "Dram" and his group Svanevit.

name: New World
description:
Svara is an acoustic poly-musical ensemble: we each bring musical ideas and experience from all over the world: India, Bali, Brazil, Europe (Eastern and Western), America. Rock, jazz, classical, contemporary creative music.

Our goal is an innovative foray into unexplored musical spaces. We are 4 musicians who have experienced deep training in a variety of traditional music forms (including western traditions) from renowned and insightful teachers. We have tried to channel that training, that exposure into a unique and organic musical expression. All of our music incorporates improvisation - some pieces are almost completely improvised; others have an open section for spontaneous exploration.

name: Sweet Teen Killing Machine
description:
Self-described as "horror-rock," Portland, Oregon-based, hard-hitting, heavy rock act Sweet Teen Killing Machine deliver an exhilarating, self-titled full-length. Comprised of ten tracks, the album delivers melodic, yet hard rock, each song the soundtrack to a fictitious horror movie.

Sweet Teen Killing Machine make guitar-rock that is as frightening as it is heart pounding. From the supernatural horror of album opener, "Curse of the Bloodwolf" and the album's first single, "City of the Shrieking Dead." To the more human terror of "Virgin White" and "New Meat," Sweet Teen Killing Machine can only be described as the sound of an insane rock beast that always seem to be chasing you.

Ideally, Sweet Teen Killing Machine wants to create soundtracks to movies; so, while writing soundtracks to fictitious movies, they take a scenario, a scene from a movie they've made up in their heads, and create the ideal soundtrack for it.

Originally a basement project between friends, jamming and having a good time, Sweet Teen Killing Machine's debut grew out of that. Never meant to release a record, the ten tracks that compile the album came out sounding so powerful; the members of the band couldn't help but release it.

Those that hear their debut full-length will take notice and go, "more please." Again, like the victims and villains in the horror movies they write soundtracks for.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Sweet Teen Killing Machine/Sweet Teen Killing Machine/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Sweet Teen Killing Machine/Sweet Teen Killing Machine/cover_200.jpg

name: Deep Life
description: Magnatune artist William Brooks aka "Swivel Neck Jones" makes a foray into atmospheric electronica and suceeds admirably at creating a mellow, underwater-ish vibe. Hammond and vibraphone swirl around crisp, mid-tempo beats for a great listen-while-you-work album. Viva the life aqautic!

name: Mix A Small Impact
description: One of the salient features of electronic music is the ability to communicate without the use of standardized elements like choruses, vocals, or often even melodies. In "Mix A Small Impact" SynchDub communicate with sounds that's not only full of simple emotions but pries out of the soul, the essence of artistry. This album is a diverse work and mix of driving electronic basslines and beats, but also full with nostalgic and melancholic sounds.

name: JS Bach Laboratory
description:
J. S. Bach Laboratory / the flute ensemble Spark

This all-Bach album features original arrangements that seek to capture the spirit of Bach's original ideas. It was recorded in Hakodate City Art Hall in 27 November 2000 and was first released in 2000 to commemorate the 250th anniversary of Bach's death.

name: JS Bach Flute Sonatas and Partita
description:
J.S. Bach's Flute Sonatas and Partita were chosen for this album as they were particularly well suited to capturing the sound and atmosphere of the hall in its pre-renovation state. Sonate h-moll fur Flote und obligates Cembalo BWV 1030 is played here with flute and cembalo without basso continuo. Partita a-moll fur Flote allein BWV 1013, known in the only surviving 18th-century manuscript as 'Solo pour une flote traversiere par J. S. Bach' is for unaccompanied flute. Sonate e-moll fur Flote und Basso Continuo BWV 1034 and Sonate E-dur fur Flote und Basso Continuo BWV 1035 are played with cembalo and basso continuo, and in this album, the basso continuo part is realized with a viola da gamba.

The recording is carefully designed to record not only the sound of the instruments but the ambient sound of the old hall using a highly sensitive one-point stereo microphone system, a specially-tuned tube amp, and a high-precision clock system. The high standard mode (96 kHz, 24 bit) and the folding of full information into CD format enable the listener to appreciate the hi-fidelity sound and precise nuances in performance.

Takashi Matsuishi plays J. S. Bach Flute Sonatas and Partita, recorded at the Hakodate City Community Centre 2011. This album provides a record of Hakodate City Community Centre Hall's unique acoustic qualities. The hall was built in 1933 in the old part of the city and used not only for various lectures and meetings but also as a concert hall. In the later part of the twentieth century, it fell into disrepair, neglect and was sadly used less and less frequently until it was eventually forgotten. Flautist Takashi Matsuishi rediscovered the hall, noting its qualities as worthy of renovation and, since 2007, he has revived its usage by producing a matinee concert series and promoting its unique properties. The hall's renewed popularity with audiences and the media interest in its revival led to a decision by Hakodate City Council to pursue its renovation, bringing its facilities up to modern standards.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Takashi Matsuishi Spark/JS Bach Flute Sonatas and Partita/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Takashi Matsuishi Spark/JS Bach Flute Sonatas and Partita/cover_200.jpg

name: Selected Duets
description:
The music for this album was chosen from the world-famous educational music book for flute beginners: Selected Duets for Flute: Volume II, compiled and edited by H. Voxman in Rubank Educational library. The music, performed by Spark's Yutaka Okawachi and Takashi Matsuishi, was recorded by recording engineer Yasuyuki Nitta in Tazawa-ko Town Hall in Akita Prefecture, Japan on 4-6 August, 2004.

The album is a useful resource for flute beginners and is ideal as background music in a variety of contexts.

name: Omogin
description:
The title of this album Omogin means 'memory is like a silver flute' in Japanese. The album contains a range of attractive ensemble pieces for two to five flutes.

It includes J. B. Boismortier's Concerts pour 5 flute-traversieres sans basse Op15 (important repertoire pieces for flute ensembles on the competition circuit), as well as Spark's original arrangements of J. S. Bach's Toccata und Fuge BWV 565.

The music was recorded in Hakodate City Art Hall on 18 August 2001 and in Toyama Art Creation Centre on 14 - 17 August 2002.

name: Preludes
description: Preludes / the flute ensemble Spark: this album features a wide variety of music from J. S. Bach to Ravel. All of the music is arranged by Spark and was recorded live in Hakodate City Art Hall on 22 March 1999. Photographer Hiroji Fukuda received the Grand Prix of the Fuji Film Commercial Photographer Competition in 1999 with the photo of Spark that features on the cover of this album. This album, originally released in 1999, is Spark's first album.

name: Beethoven Piano and Cello Works
description: One of the most beautiful pairings of piano and cello ever written, Beethoven Piano and Cello Works features the seamless musical partnership of Tanya Tomkins and Eric Zivian. Together, they handle the precarious balance between these two instruments beautifully, and even leverage it in order to bring out the intelligent passion and elegant drama that defines Beethoven's music. A wonderful album.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Tanya Tomkins and Eric Zivian/Beethoven Piano and Cello Works/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Tanya Tomkins and Eric Zivian/Beethoven Piano and Cello Works/cover_200.jpg

name: Telemann Trio Berlin
description: The largest newspaper in Germany recently described Telemann Trio Berlin's work as "the delicate correspondence of three musicians," and this collection of selected works by Vivaldi, Telemann, and C.P. Bach perfectly captures the outstanding ensemble playing of these three accomplished artists. Intimate in character even for chamber music, this album is a lovely assortment of quietly graceful selections, from genteel to joyous.

name: Teslim
description:
Teslim (Tes-LEEM) is a Turkish word that means both "commit" and "surrender," It is also a musical term for a "recurring musical theme" in Turkish music. Like a character who appears in a sequel or a repeating line in a poem, the teslim invokes a feeling of returning home. For Flexer and Hegedus, creating this music has given them a deep sense of coming home both personally and musically.

These two composers have been profoundly moved and inspired by the power of traditional Greek, Turkish, Arabic, Jewish and Balkan musics. Flexer and Hegedus listen to, study and perform repertoire from these traditions with reverence and respect. In their work as composers, they are searching for their own voice - one that takes inspiration from tradition and follows where it leads.

They feel fortunate to have found in one another a kindred spirit who shares a common artistic vision. For them, the recurring theme, the teslim, is that the trust they have in one another musically has allowed them to both commit and surrender to their own individual voices, hopefully creating something larger than either one of them. It is their wish that this voice reaches into you and that you are inspired to continue the cycle of beauty and hope.

Musicians featured on Teslim:
Kaila Flexer - violin, viola
Gari Hegedus - lauoto, baglama, bulgari, divan, cura, lavta, oud, tarhu, frame drum, penny whistle
Shira Kammen and Julian Smedley - fiddles
Olov Johansson - nyckelharpa
Liza Wallace - harp

name: The Furious Guitar
description:
Think..."What if Steve Vai, Metallica, King Crimson, Ozzy, Yes, Sabbath, Nirvana, The Beatles, STP, NIN, Zeppelin, Van Halen and Frank Zappa were all thrown in a blender with some Tequila and strawberries - that just BEGINS to tell the story...

The Furious Guitar was recorded for one reason only... To rearrange the status quo landscape of the last decade of rock and roll. "I am fucking bored to fucking tears by today's bands," is a mike e.t. quote.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Alien Mike ET/The Furious Guitar/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Alien Mike ET/The Furious Guitar/cover_200.jpg

name: Psychobabble
description:
What if you took Steve Vai, King Crimson, Frank Zappa, old Genesis, Mahavishnu Orchestra, Nirvana, Black Sabbath and Kelly Clarkson, rolled them into a joint, smoked them and then did a shot of Patron??? You'd KINDA get the Alien, but then again, nobody gets the Alien, he's too f***ed up... Uranus is a crazy place...

Guitar madness and excess of the highest order. A psychedelic yet hard rocking album of gigantic complexity. Just listen to the silky, scintillating, seductive, suicidal, sonorous, sweaty strains of music and let your brain cells melt...

name: Bach arranging and arranged
description:
Bach arranging and arranged : What happens when great composers arrange each other's works? J. S. Bach gave Pergolesi's Stabat Mater a new text and a new viola part, making a fresh piece that speaks both of Germany and Italy. Mozart gave string players the pleasure of playing fugues from the Well-tempered Clavier II: fresh arrangements by The Bach Players complete the set of all the four-part fugues from this work.

J. S. Bach, Fugues from the Well-tempered Clavier II, arranged for string quartet by W.A. Mozart, K 405, c. 1782 G. B. Pergolesi, Stabat Mater in F minor, arranged by J. S. Bach on the text of Psalm 51: 'Tilge, Hochster, meine Sunden', BWV 1083, c. 1746

Rachel Elliott: soprano
Sally Bruce-Payne: alto
Nicolette Moonen: violin
Rodolfo Richter: violin
Huw Daniel: violin
Sophie Barber: violin
Anne Schumann: viola
Alison McGillivray: cello
Elizabeth Bradley: double bass
Pawel Siwczak: organ

"The performance is a delight from start to finish. All too often this music is spoilt by the uneven results and almost invariable rivalry stemming from the partnership of a soprano with a counter-tenor. Neither Rachel Elliott nor Sally Bruce-Payne is over-assertive or over-eager to take centre stage, much preferring to preserve the penitential context of the piece and the ethereal beauty of the music ... In short, no rival version that I have heard on disc, and there are several, matches this one. Well-judged tempos and an ideal recorded sound set the seal on a particularly satisfying issue. To hell with the credit crunch, go and buy it, at once."
Nicholas Anderson, International Record Review, February 2009
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Bach Players/Bach arranging and arranged/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Bach Players/Bach arranging and arranged/cover_200.jpg

name: Every One a Chaconne
description:
Every one a chaconne

This programme is centred on the chaconne: we hear how Henry Purcell and J. S. Bach join hands in this much-loved dance form of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. Of the few works of Philipp Heinrich Erlebach that survive, we perform a suite that concludes with a chaconne. The two Bach cantatas are contrasting: BWV 150 is said to be Bach's earliest surviving cantata, BWV 78 was composed in Leipzig at the height of his career.

Rachel Elliott - soprano
Clare Wilkinson - alto
Nicholas Mulroy - tenor
Matthew Brook - bass
Nicolette Moonen - violin
Rodolfo Richter - -violin
Anne Schumann - violin / viola
Rachel Stott - viola
Alison McGillivray - cello
Elizabeth Bradley - double bass
Marion Moonen - flute
James Eastaway - oboe
Catherine Latham - oboe
Alastair Mitchell - bassoon
Silas Standage - organ / harpsichord

"There's something about the openness of sound, the sheer quality of music-making and the sense of connection between performers and composers that makes this a very special recording. Its contents explore the world of the Baroque chaconne, a secular dance form that became a staple of music for the concert room and chapel. The challenge of creating a piece above a repeated bass line certainly appealed to Bach, Purcell and the little-known Erlebach, each on inspired, inventive form in the works offered here. The Bach Players ... reach the music's emotional heart with tremendous conviction."
AS, Classic FM magazine, January 2010
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Bach Players/Every One a Chaconne/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Bach Players/Every One a Chaconne/cover_200.jpg

name: Italy versus France
description:
Italian or French? Jean Baptiste Lully and Arcangelo Corelli were the champions of these two musical styles and the main subjects of the many attempts to establish which style was better. Or could the two styles be united? This programme paints a musical picture of the seventeenth century in Europe, through the music of Corelli, Lully, and their contemporaries.

Chief among the reconcilers was the organist and composer Georg Muffat. German but of Scottish ancestry, it was he who introduced both styles to Germany. Also included are Rebel's homage to Lully and Couperin's to Corelli.

"This is the most enjoyable programme of seventeenth-century chamber music I have heard in a long time. The recording manages to capture the strings in gutty rather than silvery detail so we relax and enjoy the music without suffering from steel-string fatigue. Altogether, this is a wonderfully diplomatic programme which brings the best out in everyone - French, Italian, German and performers alike."
- Simon Heighes

name: Nun Komm
description:
Nun komm! explores the form of the French overture in two of Bach's cantatas and in a piece by a predecessor: Philipp Heinrich Erlebach. The Bach Players gather their fullest forces to perform the two thrilling cantatas. Interspersed is Isaac's 'Innsbruck, ich muss dich lassen', sung a capella and in two instrumental settings.

J.S. Bach, Cantata 'Nun komm der heiden Heiland', BWV 61
Philipp Heinrich Erlebach, Suite
Heinrich Isaac, 'Innsbruck, ich muss dich lassen'
J.S.Bach, Cantata 'In allen meinen Taten', BWV 97

"... this quite magical disc. Intimate, infused with joy and overflowing with genuine affection, this is music-making which combines enthusiasm and craftsmanship to create something both rare and precious. ... these are performances which stand out from the crowd for their freshness, vitality and sense of total commitment to the music"
Marc Rochester - International Record Review, November 2010

"This is an admirable recording: intelligently conceived and well performed. Both cantatas open with a chorus in the shape of a French overture: in no. 61 it's the slow introduction that incorporates phrases of the chorale, whereas in no. 97 the singers don't enter until the Vivace. The Erlebach piece, published in 1693, consists of a French overture followed by the usual suite of dances. The other theme of the disc is Heinrich Isaac's 'Innsbruck ich muss dich lassen', heard as a vocal quartet and as instrumental fantasias by Christian Hollander and Paul Lutkeman; and, lo and behold, it's the very tune that becomes the chorale melody at the beginning and end of 'In allen meinen Taten'. ... Nicolette Moonen plays brilliantly, as she does in the tenor aria of no. 97, with its roulades and double-stopping. Even if you don't like Bach sung one-to-a-part, you can't fail to enjoy these performances."
Richard Lawrence - Gramophone, December 2010

* IRR Outstanding disc (November 2010)
* BBC Radio 3, CD Review Disc of the Week (December 2010)

name: The Bell Hours
description:
The music on "The Bell Hours" is an eclectic and sentimental take on modern Rock and Roll, taking lyrical themes from more modern times and ideas with our impressions of love, compassion, and mindfulness (not to mention anger and jealousy) and combined it with musical themes stretching from Folk, Rock and Roll, Indie, Hip Hop, and Jazz, culminating in a rich pop music experience with amazing replay value.

The group of talented musicians inspired by the music that came together to tour the album have done an astounding job in translating the dynamics and moods live that the album captured in its recordings.

name: Easy Weather
description:
The music of The Bell Hours is an eclectic and sentimental take on modern Rock and Roll. Taking lyrical themes from more modern times and ideas with our impressions of love, compassion, and mindfulness (not to mention anger and jealousy) and combining them with musical themes stretching from Folk, Rock and Roll, Indie, Hip Hop, and Jazz, it culminates in a rich pop music experience with amazing replay value.

The group of talented musicians inspired by the music that came together to tour the album have done an astounding job in translating the dynamics and moods live that the album captured in its recordings.

name: Now is The Time
description: Awesomely nerdy new wave here folks. There's something incredibly great about the lyrics of The Bots' fun, driving techno. Verses that would be super cheesy if delivered by a carbon based life form become delightfully campy and even a little fascinating when sung by "Synthia." When she utters phrases like "You've got to keep on pushing to a higher level" in the first track or "A good groove makes a captive of me" in her clipped, disaffected computer voice, it sounds precisely the way an android band would if they were earnestly trying to imitate club music. Whether it means to or not, this music ends up being a great parody of human beings' attempts to be devastatingly sexy and cool, and it just works somehow. It's also fantastic workout music.

name: Truth_
description: The Bot's brand of awesomely nerdy new wave/techno gets even better with Truth, a driving dance album featuring the world's first virtual band. "Synthia" gets slightly darker with the lyrics on this one, and we really feel the cyber-pathos when she frets that "the world is changing so fast around me" or that she's "trying to make this life worth living." We also particularly love that she says she's "just trying to keep it real," or when she announces that "she's losing control" in her utterly detached tones ("Don't Funk With The Funk Junkie"). Yes, folks, it's true: Synthia's charms go way beyond the cyber-double-Ds that her creator dreamed up for her. Check out The Bots today.

name: Everything Comes to Those Who Wait
description:
'Everything comes to those who wait' by Celtic Reggae Revolution features a mix of reggae versions of traditional Irish songs and original Celtic/Reggae fusions. Well loved traditional Irish songs 'Raggle Taggle Gypsy' and 'Spancil Hill' are reworked in reggae style on, respectively, 'Raggle Taggle Reggae' and 'Spancil Hill/Gordon Wilson is a forgiver'. Original tune compositions include 'reggae reels' - a blend of reggae and traditional reels - 'Gandhi's Triumph' (with its delightfully syncopated rhythms) and 'The Very Hairy Rasta Fairy' and Brian Gilligan singing the laid back 'You Got to Laugh' and 'The United Mistakes of America' (complete with Hillbilly banjo and reggae beat).

The lineup features Northern Irishman Jarlath Henderson, one of the finest exponents of the uilleann pipes in the World, he is a talented and versatile musician who also plays, low whistle, tin Whistle, flute and cittern in addition to having a fine voice. He regularly guests with Scottish bands Capercaille, Salsa Celtica and Phil Cunningham. Martin MacDonald from Lewis also features on guitar and his performances on "Good People" and "Raggle Taggle Reggae" in particular, are highlights of the album. Tom Roche from Cork, (Accordion) also features on some tracks with his "Sliabh Luachra" style and Egyptian Aly Salam features on drums and percussion.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Celtic Reggae Revolution/Everything Comes to Those Who Wait/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Celtic Reggae Revolution/Everything Comes to Those Who Wait/cover_200.jpg

name: Shop Sessions
description:
HandPans (or "Hang"), are a fairly new instrument. They were Invented in Switzerland in 2000. They're a relative of the Steel Pan and are, as the name implies, designed to be played by hand.

Judith and Colin connected in late 2013 and they've been playing together ever since. Inspired and delighted by an absolute passion for the beauty and resonance of the "singing steel," Colin and Judith are The Dimples.

When starlings flock together, wheeling and darting through the sky in tight, fluid formations, it's called a murmuration. Using basic melodic structures as framework for improvisation, The Dimples create murmurations of harmony and rhythm.

name: Filmscore
description:
The Dino Haak Collective's Filmscore was conceived as the musical accompaniment to a tongue-in-cheek, yet grandiose commentary on the obscure side of existence. The band had a unified vision, to create music that transcends the usual and predictable and above all to continue their quest of finding the "perfect groove".

On board this time are German artist Dino Haak on the Mobius Megatar and vocals, DJ James Ho from Taiwan, Seattle's own Artis the Spoonman (Soundgarden, Zappa, Audislave etc.) on spoons and Alex Westcoat (Say Hi!, David Banzan) on the drums. With "A herd of wild Elephants coming right at you", "You guys are so Star Wars", "and a Heavy Nintendo vibe", the music transcends a variety of genres and attracts fans of artists such as System of A Down, Peter Gabriel, King Crimson, The Prodigy and George Clinton.

name: Switzerland Your Light Is On
description:
With "Switzerland Your Light is On", The Dino Haak Collective is again staying true to their unique style and mission of creating the unusual. Like every DHC album, it has its own idea and conceptual script.

S.Y.L.I.O can be seen as the band's tough and gritty "American" album. It is heavy, it is dark, and in true DHC tradition, ever so focused on the groove. "Switzerland Your Light is On" comes with a healthy, charming dose of controlled anger along with the usual tongue-in-cheek humor the band is known for. On board with Dino Haak and The Collective this time are Troy Glessner on guitars, Sean Siner on drums with guest musicians Marino Corriea (Hammond organ) and Phil Peterson (cello, trumpet).
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Dino Haak Collective/Switzerland Your Light Is On/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Dino Haak Collective/Switzerland Your Light Is On/cover_200.jpg

name: Black and White
description:
"The Dirty Love" definitely have Punk sensibilities and attitude, but the music is far more intricate than your average Punk band. There is a clear sound and excellent instrumental passages."

The band writes of this album:
When writing Black and White we wanted to touch on subjects that really provoked us and just let people have it. I think its a diverse record in the way of styles, there is something for everyone on here. Its definitely a more raw album than our previous and has plenty of live feeling energy, which is something else we really wanted to do this time around. All in all its 10 songs of pure bliss, great to drive to and I think people will relate to the messages being said here.

name: Hurricane Tide
description: Hurricane tide is a stripped back version of "The Dirty Love's" normal hard rocking self. Featuring well written songs from the heart, loads of great melody and some monster guitar solos that make your ears just want to melt. It's raw, and for the most part live: a must have for the classic rock/punk/acoustic music lover.

name: Roulette Romance
description: We wrote Roulette Romance in '09 and we were still pretty young. It has got a lot of attitude and speed about it and some really good catchy tracks that people seem to like. It is rock'n roll and it is pop and it even features a slow track with an acoustic guitar.

name: All Directions
description:
All Directions is the first album by The Donnis Trio released in 2007. The album's mix of rock, folk, and reggae, clearly showed they had a disregard for marketing and pigeon holing themselves into one specific style. However, the songwriting and feel of the music is top notch.

Fuelled by the songwriting of Nate Donnis and the production of Phil Woodring the music has honesty, simplicity, and complexity. A few of the songs off the album regularly receive over 1 million plays every 3 months on Pandora Radio. If your a Dave Matthews Fan, a Nick Drake Fan, or even Tom Waits your going to love this.

name: Cole Pond
description:
Most of the tracks on this album are drawn from the lens of nature and childhood memories. Driving in the summer to vacation at Cole Pond with the family or feeling the warmth of a fire lit room in the winter. The music sought to capture the magic of these experiences as they were so fondly recollected.

This is a great album to listen to while driving through the country and small towns or just something to put on at home when you want to have some wine and relax.

"Cole Pond" is collection of folk songs released by The Donnis Trio in 2012.

name: EP One
description:
The Easton Ellises aim to create music for auditoriums as much as for dance floors. The result is a combination of side chained electronic music with a mix of rock n' roll. A synthesizer making love to a Les Paul. A TR808 transgendered into a Ludwig supraphonic.

It's all about sex, love, fantasies and addictions. Painted women, impossible love, liquor and machine guns.

name: A Diary of Occurrences
description:
A Diary of Occurrences EP is a collection of 7 tracks each composed to reflect an atmosphere or memory. Working again with loop based and system based composition techniques, The glimmer room have come up with the perfect antidote to the relative starkness of the previous album I Remain. The light and sometimes playful melodies float over a dreamy bed of recorded loops and sound manipulation, giving A Diary of Occurrences a very blurred, melancholic and distant atmosphere.

"The main inspiration for this recording started with a dream I'd had, wherein I lived in a big and old rambling house that was set very much in keeping with a early 1900's country house. This developed into a fascination with the inhabitants of the house and the stories and the memories that by now are lost in time forever".
Andy Condon.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/the glimmer room/A Diary of Occurrences/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/the glimmer room/A Diary of Occurrences/cover_200.jpg

name: grey mirrors
description:
Grey Mirrors is the second album from the unique and groundbreaking the glimmer room. It builds on what has gone before but this time the atmosphere is everything. A gentle bird song beckons you into the piece and what follows is a 42 minute, epic journey though layers of time and emotion.

The glimmer room's strengths lie in the ability to present supremely melodic structures within a work with such emotional depth. In some passages you are cocooned in a warm luminescence, feeling safe and untouchable as lush choral washes wrap around you. Then the mood changes and you are thrown into an unsettling, barren and misty landscape where you are confronted by the sinister scraping of digital bits and bytes being smashed around a processor. As urgently as it arrives it is gone and you are left floating, clarified in a place of great beauty.

Heralded as the new benchmark for the chill out album, Grey Mirrors is almost a meditation. But every journey is as individual as the listener.

The ambience of the piece has been likened to the long grandiose intros of Pink Floyd with the overpowering Englishness of John Foxx's Cathedral Oceans. While musically comparisons range from Leftfield's Melt, the KLF's Chill Out, to the more chilled tracks from The Future Sound of London. Add to this a sprinkle of sound design from Delia Derbyshire and you will be close to the sound of this unique album.

name: I remain
description:
This album is a return to a more sparse sound, first heard on the band's album "Grey Mirrors". It uses multiloop based systems similar to the systems of Brian Eno to build up the basic tracks before the more melodic elements where produced. This provided the machines the space they needed to breath and throw up some truly intriguing avenues that would not have been explored with a more conventional approach to the composition. Slow long ambient loops that always develop and mutate underpin the melancholic washes of sound and melodies.

In essence it is the album where the machines finally have became true friends. "I Remain" is an album presented as one continuous piece of music but split into 9 discrete movements.

name: now we are six
description:
Following on from 2004's Grey Mirrors, this new release looks to all the lost jewels, the one off tracks composed with a purpose in mind, throughout The Glimmer Room's first 6 years.

The Glimmer Room's Andy picks up the story and the idea came about like most good ideas, sat round a table in a pub with a group of close friends. At one point in the evening he was asked, "what happened to all the tracks that never made it onto your albums?" he explained that a fair few had been used on magazine cover disks and compilations, but it started him thinking about all those pieces of music, six years worth of tracks spread all over the globe. What chance did people have of hearing all of them? With this thought still fresh in his mind, the next day he started to find all the old masters. Over the next few weeks he worked on mastering them and finding a running order that ran like an album and not just a collection of pieces.

While he was working on this he started to get the feeling that he was bringing them all back home, safe under one roof. Now We Are Six contains a vast mixture of rare studio, live and re-mixed tracks, giving the listener a chance to hear some of The Glimmer Room's most obscured from view, but totally inspired and atmospheric moments to date, in one sitting.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/the glimmer room/now we are six/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/the glimmer room/now we are six/cover_200.jpg

name: Open Sezame
description:
A darkly pleasing romp through industrial/electronic/hard-rock genres.

The artist (The Great Mooklaa Herashaa) writes: I am attempting to take the listener on a journey, a journey that mirrors my own, in that it follows my own inner search for the music inside to let itself out into reality.

I start with more classic structured songs like Stomp and Discipline which stem from my own past in gothic and industrial music with a hint of BDSM bondage for flare.

Then, add definite parts and arrangements in more experimental pieces with more emotion and unusual sounds and beats of their own such as Multch, Angel and Bloodsong.

Finally, into the realm of trance like ambient states through pieces like Host Of Siafu and an almost psychedelic journey into the underworld itself with Syclicle and The Sterile InsomNiac.

My hope is that the listener when finished will have the feeling of discovering that something special that only music can bring.

name: Apa Ya
description: Full of spice, color, and heat, Apa Ya fuses traditional world music with modern beats and highly advanced audio design to create music in entirely new, never-before-heard dialect of rhythm and sound. This album is a great example of how the world genre is moving into more sophisticated territory without losing any vibrancy. It's one of those albums that simply must be heard to be appreciated.

name: Bereru
description:
Bereru is a diversified mixture of fresh and experimental songs between pop, rock and electronica.

Again, Andreas Ecker aka The Headroom Project fuses unusual sound and rhythmic performances with the advanced vocal design using contemporary special software.

Furthermore, Bereru invites the listener to discover sounds never or rarely heard in a musical context, for example the noise of a cappuccino machine which represents the essential element of the beat on "Kiss Someday Babe". Or the crunch of old trees together with a shaman voice on "700 Miles to Nuuk", Watergongs and whispered voices in front of dark machine noises, extremely processed virtual blues guitar solo on "Vanesh da Ginda". Last but not least, the voices of Sigrid Haverkamp on "Funky Star" and "Forever", and Jaqueline Scheider on "I Will Follow" enrich the album with power, personality and charm.

name: Ciri a Doro
description: Andreas Ecker delivers another batch of his incredibly charismatic, unique take on world music, here conceived as a sleek, futuristic mash-up of imaginary languages layered over mid-tempo electronic beats and jazz-tinged melodies. Artists making this kind of music typically cite bands like Dead Can Dance and Delirium as influences, but Ecker says his run more along the lines of King Crimson, Frank Zappa, and Peter Gabriel. You can really hear the humor and crazy energy of these influences in the music, which sounds like the lost soundtrack to The Fifth Element. A groovy, surprising album-full of exotic flavor and vivid atmospheres. Listen for the fantastic bass performance by Ecker too.

name: COS
description:
The seventh album of The Headroom Project is a homage of the charismatic and expressive voice of Anna B. who wrote all the lyrics, too. Anna B. was born in South Africa and traveled around the whole world. Today she lives in Munich, Germany. In the 90s she climbed the international charts with some Mainstream pop music hits. On this album, Anna exhibits her talent for a further range of musical expressiveness. Together with the powerful beats and unconventional instrumental arrangements, a very special sound of electronic rock is produced.

All the tracks were recorded in 2005 and have been completely re-mastered for release in 2010. The last song of this mini album is a bonus track in German.

name: Dominus Illuminato Mea
description:
"Dominus Illuminato Mea" is the result of an outstanding collaboration between Andreas Ecker (aka "The Headroom Project)" and 5 charismatic artists: Liliana Flores, Jaqueline Schwarz, Peter M. Mahr, Eberhard Geitz and Otto Reiter.

Liliana Flores, Mexico City: Vocals ? lyrics for track 10 "Kathrina". Liliana is an actrice, song writer and tv-moderator in Mexico. (She was on the screen for VH1 Latin America during 2004 and 2008.)

Jaqueline Schwarz, Vienna, Austria: Vocals on track 7 "selve amiche" and track 8 "halla hey". Jaqueline is a trained singer (classical and jazz) and earns her money by singing on funerals.

Peter M. Mahr, Vienna, Austria: composition, arrangement, keys, sound programming, mix on track 5 "water meditation", track 6 "blue darkness", track 7 "selve amiche", track 8 "halla heij", composition, arrangement, keys, sound programming, mix and voice on track 9 "2k7". See petermmahr.com (blog).

Eberhard Geitz, Weserbergland, Germany: composition, arrangement, sound programming, keys on track 5 "water meditation", additional keys on track 6 "blue darkness", the incredible virtual guitar solo on track 8 "halla heij", drum programming ? virtual guitar on track 9 "2k7".

Otto Reiter: fretless bass on track 8 "halla heij".

Andreas Ecker, Bonn, Germany: drum programming on track 6 "blue darkness", drum programming and voice edition on track 7 "selve amiche", drum programming and keys on track 8 "halla heij". All instruments, arrangement, composition, mix on track 1-4 and 9-14.

name: Haifa
description: Do you want to discover a never before heard sound? This album invites you to take a vivid and vibrant journey across the world of music - without borders or limits. Using the latest voodoo-studio-technology Andreas Ecker (aka The Headroom Project) merges hypnotic rhythms with expressive ethno vocals and hyper-real instruments to create extraordinary music beyond all known genres. Alpine Choirs, Polynesian war-shouts, Mongolian overtone-singers, fragile, morbid and heartbreaking guitar-riffs are only a few of the stations you will pass during this totally unique musical journey.

name: Jetuton Andawai
description: Combining amazing sound design with music from Africa, the Middle East, and Asia, Jetuton Andawai is one of the most vibrant albums we've heard this year. With dazzling vocals, fantastic bass work, and studio voodoo that's just completely off the hook, it doesn't sound like anything else out there. "Linda Morena" is the graceful, near-a cappella intro, and things proceed to get more and more interesting after that. "Jetuton Andawai" sounds like a Bollywood record being played backwards to Peter Gabriel, and "Lost World" is even more trippy, with tumbling, echoey loops and driving bass. "Manu Yu" has a mellow yet infectious groove, and the excellent "Copeuse Concon" combines future-classical Indian vocals with smoky jazz. None of the influences here seem like they should work together (islandy xylophones in a blues track?), but they not only succeed, they succeed wildly for a potent, totally unique sound. "Yesterday" is the most radio friendly track on the album, with pretty vocals by Sigrid Havercamp. But in true Headroom fashion, most of the vocals of Jetuton Andawai are shaped and manipulated to the point where they form new, never before heard languages. It's world pop for the global village.

name: In Kananga
description:
In Kananga transports the heat, pure power and color of West/Central Africa between Tanger (Marocco) and Kananga (Kongo). There we meet the famous medicine man.

The inseparable force of rhythm and harmonies creates floating pictures you never imagined before. The track "How to ride an elephant" explains better that any special elephant-user-guide how to do what it says.

The song "Cutzi" is sung in Purepecha (the language of the Central Mexican Indians) and is an entrance to deeper meditation. Perhaps you will find here even more spiritual power than in the wise words of the medicine man. "Lovedrive" is a rare but at the same time impressive dance somewhere between industrial and trip hop.

Andreas Ecker (aka The Headroom Project), designed new instrument phrases by separating the overtones from existing samples and treating them like independent notes, changing their time-lapses and pitch-curves. You can hear the results on "fragile piano suffering under micro organismas" or on "Gerome" (where the percussion hits in the background).

Andreas Ecker: all instruments, arrangements, mixes. Vocals on "In Kananga"
Liliana Flores: Vocals on "Cutzi" and "Fuimos Cosmos"
Sigrid Haverkamp: Vocals on "Lovedrive" and "Outside"
Coverphoto: Jorn Daberkow (Landscape: Yoshua Tree National Park)
Cover Design: Andreas Ecker

name: Polaris
description:
Polaris combines ethno vocals with sometimes smooth, sometimes massive electronic beats and a huge range of wide-ranging instruments. World percussion meets rare and strange tone generators like ancient glass bowls or conch shell horns.

Most of the vocals consist of cutted and recomposed syllables of exotic languages - except "Let there be silence", sung by Sigrid Haverkamp. The tracks 7 to 11 are experimental rhythmic soundscapes including song-like fragments, shaman singer (Polaris) or slow moving trombones over a hypntoic monotone bass (Roll ? Roll ? Roll).

Andreas Ecker: all instruments, arrangements, mixes
Sigrid Haverkamp: vocals on "Let there be Silence"
Arik Lucian Kami Ecker: baby breath-noises on "Polaris"
Cover Design: Andreas Ecker

name: La Follia Itinerante
description:
La Follia Itinerante. The itinerant madness. Der Fahrende Wahnsinn.

It is that moment in time and place when the soul catches a slow motion glimpse of itself traveling willy-nilly through the maelstrom of the great vortex. At once noble and base, it is coloured in a chromatic blue melancholy and dry red pathos. There too is the peace that comes with acceptance of one's fate... and the anguished impossibility of not struggling against this same fate... La Follia Itinerante holds up a mirror that we may see ourselves as we really are: beggars before God. And makes us laugh at our own pitiful and ludicrous condition.

A true Follia is unique at each playing. It exists for a moment and then vanishes. This one was caught on a warm and sunny afternoon in a garden house on the southern slopes of the Schwarzwald. It takes as inspiration the Follias of Nicholas Chedeville, Corelli, Vivaldi, Marais and the many other composers, known and unknown, who have added to our treasure store of Follias.

name: Italian Cantatas and Sonatas (GF Handel and Caldara)
description: Two of the most dramatic and emotional cantatas of the Baroque period for alto voice share this album with a colorful variety of sonatas from Handel and Caldara. Countertenor Jay Carte joins the Kingsbury Ensemble in this celebration of two of the most successful of Italian opera: GF Handel and Antonio Caldara.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Kingsbury Ensemble/Italian Cantatas and Sonatas (GF Handel and Caldara)/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Kingsbury Ensemble/Italian Cantatas and Sonatas (GF Handel and Caldara)/cover_200.jpg

name: Berlin
description: Ok, Berlin is just so damn sexy. Angular, androgynous, pouty?it's a Bowie/Siouxsie-influenced urchin of an album that'll have you strutting around the house like a Milanese model on a Fashion Week catwalk. Highlights include the smouldering opener "Impressions," the world's only New Wave drinking song "We Didn't Go," and the deliciously disaffected "Tap At Floes." Skeptics take note: this is not the trend-hopping New Wave of the last few years; this the direct descendent of New Wave...its legitimate heir.

name: Erase
description: For a decidedly new wave album, there's a lot of passion and emotion on Erase. Danyx's brooding, Nico-esque voice has a searching quality about it, and there are some great moments when it breaks out of its stylized discontent to become genuinely melodic and, fleetingly, joyous. Recommended tracks include "Face," "Delicate," the Cure-tinged "Tied," and "Take Me to the World," a bittersweet but ultimately upbeat song that hints at what's to come on The Kokoon's incredible follow-up Berlin.

name: No 3
description: The tunes on No.3 are catchy, full of hooks and energy while Danyx' voice shows sensitivity and emotions in a way never heard before. The headling song "I'd love to go on" might be the first - yes! - love song they've ever done but without the missing of tragedy and beautiful suffering in a shape of big emotion. "No.3" covers a new step in the music biography of The Kokoon.

name: The Lost Mode
description:
Medieval music meets living modal music traditions: The Lost Mode features an eclectic set of music from the Middle Ages, as well as melodies from Sephardic, North African, Armenian, Breton, and Basque modal traditions. Our interpretations are meant to extend, complement, and bridge the gap between written sources and oral transmission.

New compositions based on medieval models stand next to their century-old counterparts. Some melodies are lifted out of their original context, presented in a different meter, or brought to life on instruments that would not have been known in the music's original culture. The result: a multi-layered, time-and boundary-crossing collection of tones, timbres, textures, lovingly held together by the common thread of mode.

name: Crisis
description:
CRISIS is the brain child of Los Angeles based artist Ajax Garcia and NEWSTED drummer Jesus Mendez Jr.

During The Napoleon Blownaparts US tour stint supporting KISS and WEEZER back in 2001 the band had plans to record their long awaited followup to their 1998 album "Thrill Hype" but due to conflicting schedules plans to record were put on hold as drummer Jesus Mendez Jr. had prior commitments to his other band NEWSTED (see Jason Newsted of METALLICA).

Mendez and Ajax along with new recruit Eric Griffin (MURDER DOLLS) on bass guitar finally entered the studio to begin tracking but because of musical differences the band never got passed the recordings of just two cover tracks with Griffin as part of the line up. The two tracks that were recorded were ultimately released as part of Jetboys Of Babylon (a tribute to The New York Dolls album) which featured David Johansen himself and Steve Jones of The Sex Pistols. Ajax, Mendez and Griffin contributed a blistering version of the Dolls classic Puss In Boots.

Griffin's replacement was bassist Doug Wellmon a young punk rocker from Hollywood California and a former member of the band Pipedown.

When the two musicians finally began tracking they recruited a number of musicians to guest on what would become the CRISIS album including legendary blues musicians John Clifton on Harmonica and the legendary Edward Burke on piano. The 70 year old Edward Burke also played with the Ike and Tina Turner Review in the 1970's. Long time friend and guitarist Jessie Farnsworth also of NEWSTED completed the line up and CRISIS was finally released in 2010. AMERICA'S TIRE company used the opening track HELL YEAH as part of their national advertising campaign and the UK CLASSIC ROCK MAGAZINE picked up on the second single MY SPACE PICTURES for their tribute to Guns N' Roses insert Sons Of Guns.

Sonically CRISIS is a raw mix of punk rock and garage rock and roll with heavy doses of soul and the blues. Drawing influences from the likes of The Rolling Stones, New York Dolls, The Stooges and heavy tip of the hat to Chuck Berry the CRISIS album takes you on a dark trip down a seedier side of Hollywood California not advertised to tourists.

The classic slash and burn guitars, frantic drumming under the impressive vocal range of guitarist/vocalist Ajax Garcia make up this low-fi gem.

Recognized for his powerful, raw, biting but truthful commentary on our cultural and social condition, Ajax' work on the song "Hedonistic Babies" resonates on every level! Garcia is a post postmodern rarity of authentic swagger and angst, continually serving up his Fresno-born and Hollywood-bred artistry on his own terms. Crisis Starts Now!
Music and street art photographer Karin Lindberg Freda, 2013

name: Thrill Hype
description: Biting guitars and gritty, pissed off rock vocals anyone? Yes please. Napoleon Blown Aparts are like a punked up Guns 'N Roses with a dash of The Dolls (See "Unlucky Star"). Ajax Garcia's voice sounds absolutely great on this album, and we can't get enough of his crystal clear, spot-on guitar work either. These guys are clearly rock purists. We like-y. Oh and check out "Sonny" for a totally unexpected combination of bongo drums and "motherfucker" references.

name: Keep Your Head Up
description: This album is packed with gritty grooves, sensual female vocals, funky bass and drums and old style keys. A combination of vocal tracks and purely instrumental tunes inspired by 70's cop show soundtracks and Funk Club music take the listener back to a time of car chases through litter strewn alleys, Afro haircuts, purple flairs and smoky bars. So, kick back and enjoy...
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Old Recruits/Keep Your Head Up/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Old Recruits/Keep Your Head Up/cover_200.jpg

name: Public Service Announcement
description: John writes: Keith Adams is a professional drummer who--on the side--writes really perfect pop rock that make me smile.

name: Public Service Announcement (Instrumental)
description:
This instrumental version of the Proper Authorities' 2009 Magnatune release "Public Service Announcement" provides a modern pop rock bed of groove, drama, intensity, and fun. With the exception of the opening track, the originally lyric-free track "The Supermachine Looks Much Bigger on TV," this collection of songs focuses on a non-vocal soundscape of various moods and timbres. Sometimes playful, sometimes serene, sometimes epic, sometimes melancholic, these tracks are always interesting.

When discussing the approach to writing the original album, Proper Authorities' brainchild Keith Adams described its primary theme as "how time affects our approaches to living... a song about 'You can accomplish anything you want' has more weight and realism to it when you add 'But you'd better step up to the task before it's too late.'"

Though the words are absent, the urgency and attitude of these songs is still very much present. The hard-edged guitar work and no-holds-barred drums of the track "Losing The Now" evokes a feel of a military march with victorious and timely purpose. The electro-rock synth stylings and slinky bass work of "Make A Choice For Me" suggest a cold, urban environment and an immediacy of action required. And songs like "The Ninth Life Jitters" and "Whodunit" are just plain fun rock songs! Enjoy "Public Service Announcement: Instrumental"!

name: One Armed Bandits
description:
One Armed Bandits is a multi-faceted menu of beat-heavy, darkened R'n'B/Soul, with each song having a distinctly different influence and flavor from the next. There are wide variations, from the funky "Stuck in RED", to the ethereal "My Medicine", to the highly danceable "Slight of Hand" and "But You're Mine", the dirge-like "Daddy May I", and the rockin' "Ain't the Madonna, Ain't Your Whore".

However, even with this wide a palette, the group never loses its own cohesive, identifiable sound. It remains consistent across the board, with wah-wah guitars, saucy horns, liberal use of electronics and samples, and sultry vocals. With all its cohesive range, "One Armed Bandits" delivers.

name: Back Home
description:
True fans of country music will find the perfect marriage of traditional and modern country in The Ranchhands' "Back Home" album.

Well crafted songs, a powerful and heartfelt vocal delivery by Mickey Kennedy, electrifying fiddle playing by Chris Tedesco, and lush 3 and 4 part vocal harmonies make this record soar. Glowing reviews from Texas to France gave this album and band international acclaim and a worldwide fanbase that continues to grow.

name: Driven
description:
The most recent release from The Ranchhands has solidified their position as a worldwide force on the country music scene.

Driven embodies the best elements of today's country music, featuring the rocking fiddle playing of Chris Tedesco, and the star-quality vocal performance of Mickey Kennedy.

The songs cover a wide range of emotions and settings, from getting lost in a vacation daydream, to the sudden loss of a loved one, to the comical everyday stories at a small town diner, to a song about a rockin country Friday night in the heart of Texas. While keeping true to country music, this albm will appeal to music fans of many different genres.

name: Garden of Fugitives
description: Garden of Fugitives continues the theme of creating electronic music with a heart and soul. At times more introspective and reflective than their previous "10 Raptures" album, but still with tracks of power, rhythm and melody. From harsh, distorted leads to sweet, soaring strings, from soft acoustic drums to club spec beats Garden of Fugitives is a journey through all that electronic music can offer. If you thought you didn't like electronic, take a listen and think again.

name: Welcome to Mania
description: Welcome to Mania continues to explore electronic music with a heart and mixes melodic, organic phrases with electro dance and dubstep inspired bass and rhythm. Themes of contrast and change are explored by combining and juxtaposing old and new, rhythmic and melodic, syncopation and straight. Encompassing darker, dirtier moods than the two previous albums in the trilogy, Welcome to Mania completes the journey through the head of ThE rApTuRe...for now.....

name: Rush
description:
On this album I wanted to explore the current fashion for analogue synthesis and pure analogue sounds, placed against different styles of modern dance music but also continuing my efforts to write electronic music which takes the listener on a journey in every song. This album was six months in the making; written, recorded and produced in the second half of 2013.

The 11 tracks include rave, trip-hop, trance, rap and drum ? bass influenced music unified by electrifying, screaming leads, pounding drums and complex arrangements, interspersed with more vocal sections than in previous albums.

Play this on your iPod in the gym and run faster, jump higher and hit harder. Play it on your car radio and I can't be held responsible for your speeding fines! Please enjoy...Rush.

name: 10 Raptures
description:
Taking inspiration from early Jean Michel Jarre and 80's analogue synth sounds, then combining contemporary dance beats and rhythms with a classical approach to form and structure, the album seeks to take dance music out of the clubs and place it firmly into a listening environment.

The tracks on 10 Raptures are in equal part dance, ambient and trance with a dose of electro thrown in for good measure. 10 Raptures was written, recorded and produced over the course of 10 months from Spring 2011 onwards. Using a multitude of hardware and software synthesizers, samples, drum machines and effects, the tracks were written, recorded, produced and mastered in-house at Mount Street Studio near London.

name: 2000Hz
description:
Taking the listener on a journey through trance, dub, drum and bass and back, it's best played loud; preferably in a dark club with lots of flashing lights and smoke.

Alternatively, a phone and headphones will do just fine...whichever way you listen, please enjoy more electronica with a heart. 2000Hz is the fourth album from UK producer "The Rapture".

name: House of Weather
description:
The reminding ideas are brought about by the use of pressure, command, and authorization. They bring to mind a human being's product of mental activity and high levels of industrialized standards of living by combining all of one's characteristics. There are good ideas and bad ideas. There are rules, and there are animals. Some vegetables can bring you happiness. Other foods can give you just one final remaining idea. Whatever the case may be, you will save the day. This is where we all take a deep breath and wait for August to appear again and again and again and again and again.

Vegetables
Spending thoughts make us forget everything. The notes we save will never be read. You may disagree, but plates don't. Circle around and around the world until we all catch the fever. Let's give the dog a bath. Let's give ourselves a bath. Don't forget to open the envelope before we jump in. This envelope contains the word of the day. Positively, nothing will go as planned. Nowhere can we run. Nowhere can we hide. We water the earth. We water the mouths. Unacceptable.

Rules for Animals
We weren't suppose to be reasoning with life. We demand rules. No one should go through this. Bitched again and again. Flies are for flying, not dropping. Doors are for opening. Remember readers. Remember the word of the day. Mark it down forever. We are grabbing our belongings and coming for you now. Stay put and hide. Then, it is your job to get us out. Show us a way out, please.

Do You Understand?
Boom Down. Boom Down. Can you hear me? Again down. Boom Down. I'm calling your name. Unbelievable down. All down. Again down. I can hear you. Down boom down. Bow down again down. Got you. Go

August
Attention, Everyone here had disordered. This doesn't feel real, but it is. Or is it? We got here from a flash of a light. It looks like we used to live here, but it's different. Everyone sides with everyone. Sometimes there is a glitch and a restart. Bring along fall for future assistance. It's quite peaceful here, but something is majorly fucked up. Holy shit, that person is floating. I gotta run.

Swarm of Bees
We've accepted our sightseeing. Surrounding thy swordsmen with our spores, we are the air. This battle begins at birth. We have a circle we can't get out of. The circle can expand into infinity, but we can't leave the circle. Got to just accept this. We can't leave the circle. Welcome new friends of friends. We know each other, but we don't. Who are you? How do I know you? We are all nervous. Sit. Relax yourself. There are plots we must avoid. The net prank is a pitfall. AVOID.

The Remaining Idea
Relaxed, wow, sounds like fresh flowers in the distance. Wait, fresh flowers have sound now. We must have fallen into the trap. Now, we have crossed our hearing and smelling. The heat around us. This gets stronger around Hope Hill. She's one big volcano bursting down some of our huts. We just had another restart. Crawl backflipper star. We feel the energy inside you. Each picture is worth a galaxy

Good Clown, Bad Clown
The cartoons keep popping on cue. Look at our costume. Every time the funny friends laugh and joke. While singing to the boring children, We stopped performing miracles years ago. What does this mean? We are being really hard on ourselves. Have another drink and another. Tell the kids to stay away from the ice cream man. He's getting more attention this way. I take pride in what I do, and all this guy does is drive up in a moving shed with wheels with a music box and...... what a loser

This is Where We Breathe
So glad we got away. This is cloud nineteen hundred and twenty thousand that we have counted pass us. Much lower now, everyone has forgotten up to 70 years before this trip. Inhale. Why are we here? Exhale. The wind is changing colors on us. We get on this boat, we drift down this river. Now the upstairs door to the weather can't control us.

Save the New Day
Rush the Riches Cavern. The fun never started. We die. Over the river are alive people. This is where we tell fun lies and truth beyond. Gravity and rocks. Save the sunshine.

I Can Bring You Happiness
Crease, dent, and polish bad apples. Remind me again to remind me ideas. Remind GOOD people ideas that happiness is correct. Never Fall. Never Fail. Always on time. Correct? Yes. Always happy. Remember forever.

name: Bach Cantatas
description: This deeply beautiful recording presents two of Bach's cantatas for solo voice, one-Weichet nur-a celebratory wedding ode and the other his celebrated masterpiece for the Feast of the Purification of the Virgin. Internationally acclaimed mezzo-soprano Dominique Labelle and three time Grammy nominee Sanford Sylvan lend their incredible voices to the Sarasa Ensemble in order to depict both the idyllic, pagan landscape of the first work, and the luminous, "lullaby to the soul" of the second. A third work-Liebster Jesu-features a "sacred dialogue" between these two sublime voices, and the entire album makes clear why The Sarasa Ensemble is so often praised for its great clarity of style.

name: A Baroque Mosaic
description: Hailed for its "great clarity" and "irresistible energy," The Sarasa Ensemble performs Vivaldi, Bach, Handel and other compositions from the early Baroque through the Romantic eras. This album shows off the ensemble's masterful sense of cadence and rich, lucid tones. Full liner notes included with album download!

name: Coalizione del Volere
description:
Coalizione del Volere, the new album from The Seldon Plan, is a direct descendant of their video sessions - reflective of a desire of the band to step back to a more Dischord-era-like guitar-driven rock sound, akin to 2005's Making Circles but with the softer, more mature edge of 2007's The Collective Now. On Coalizione del Volere, the band seems intent on exploring a more angular guitar rock sound within the context of focused melodies and textured intricate harmonies.

Listeners who have enjoyed The Seldon Plan through their first four records will delight as The Big Takeover has at the "...Baltimore foursome's continued maturation." To this end, the band presents a mature Seldon Plan sound, an amalgam of influences that can be heard but do not define Coalizione del Volere. The use of strong and repeatable melodies is reminiscent of the American Analog Set, yet the technicolor layers of Coalizione del Volere bring to mind Let Go-era Nada Surf and The Californian by Sunday's Best. To drive home this past/present dichotomy The Seldon Plan has teamed up again with engineer Frank Marchand (The Thermals, Bob Mould), who worked with the band on 2005's Making Circles, and 2007's The Collective Now.

name: Making Circles
description: The highly nuanced indie rock of The Seldon Plan combines clean, lilting harmonies with a brooding emo undercurrent...kind of like if Brian Wilson and Ian MacKaye had co-produced a Cure album. The real life producers of Making Circles are every bit the fantasy pairing too: Frank Marchand is known for his work with Bob Mould and Good Charlotte, and Charlie Pilzer for his with Ida and The Kennedys. Together, they helped The Seldon Plan perfect its thoughtful, polished sound while leaving in all the dire elements that keep it from being too settled or safe. Better yet, Making Circles is absolutely riddled with standout tracks including "Holding Patterns Are Slow," and "Top Left Corner," a mesmerizingly beautiful and poignant song.

name: The Collective Now
description: Highly polished yet exquisitely laid back indie rock: "What impresses us most about this band's music is how unpretentious it is. The smooth, ultra-hummable songs on this CD flow by like big fluffy clouds. After spinning this disc a few times...we can't decide which we like better, the debut album (Making Circles)...or this? Actually and in fact, we prefer both as they are each equally satisfying and superb." --Babysue. Standout tracks include "Colored Lenses," "Seraphim" and our favorite, the deceptively catchy "Modern Vigil."

name: Lost And Found And Lost
description:
Whimsical, nostalgic indie pop tells the story of expectant hope and recession blues.

The Seldon Plan reemerges with whimsy with their highly anticipated album LOST AND FOUND AND LOST, a worthy follow-up to their 2007 record THE COLLECTIVE NOW. Praised for its "catchy simple melodies awash with lush vocals, hip full guitars, and a hint of Flaming Lips" by artist/composer Mark Degli Antoni (David Byrne/Soul Coughing) and dubbed "smart pop with no wasted space" by record producer Brian McTernan (Senses Fail/Piebald/Thrice), LOST AND FOUND AND LOST plays with images of childhood nostalgia to embrace the economic and political pendulum.

The Baltimore-based indie pop rockers are known for their "tuneful-wistful rock" (The Washington Post) and "literate, yet still youthful" (Allmusic) sound. Aptly named, LOST AND FOUND AND LOST portrays the juxtaposition of excitement and uncertainty in a country undergoing a changing political situation. "These were the hardest lyrics I've ever had to write, but now that they're out, I feel really energized," says singer/songwriter Michael Nestor.

Calling their latest LP "a burst of new flavor", The Big Takeover's Jack Rabid expressed delight at the "Baltimore foursome's continued maturation" and compared it favorably to "melodic pop favorites such as Feelies' offshoot Wild Carnation, Winnipeg's wonderful Weakerthans, great Scots Camera Obscura, and Portland's Dimes."
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Seldon Plan/Lost And Found And Lost/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Seldon Plan/Lost And Found And Lost/cover_200.jpg

name: Geeking Dream
description: The Strap-Ons aren't going to waste any of your time, oh no. They cut straight to the chase and bring THE ROCK exactly the way it was meant to be brought: edgy, messy, sexy. Twenty five shot glasses full of high octane guitars and awesomely bad attitude really do it for us (plus a healthy dose of humor too -- "Wicca Chicka" is hysterically funny).
