You're gonna wanna have this one on hand for those days when you feel like telling everyone where to go. Check out "This Place Sucks" to see what we mean. A fantastically unsubtle album that hits the bullseye, straight-on.

name: We'll Go Down Fighting
description:
Gritty, homegrown, ghetto tech rock and roll with driving guitars, insane drum solos, hints of punk, and a side of mellow. A continuation of prophetic messages, experiences, and personal demons hidden among inimitable musicianship, lyrics, and passionate vocals.

A follow up to 2008's I'm Sorry LA, We'll Go Down Fighting finds The Suicide Denial hitting their musical stride and pushing the envelope between rock and synth rock.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Suicide Denial/We'll Go Down Fighting/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Suicide Denial/We'll Go Down Fighting/cover_200.jpg

name: Ohio Sessions, April to June
description:
These three EPs, combined into an album, each shows different sides of the rock/prog/electro-rock sound that is The Town Monster. Each EP explores a different musical concept.

The three shorts from the April EP are almost entirely electronic and feature a much snappier, more polished sound than the previous EPs. This one treads bizarre yet poppy territory, coming off like a Burlesque/New Wave mashup of Radiohead and Faith No More. "Atari Girl" is a raging beast of a track with multiple layers of bass, synth choirs, and some demented big top rapping. "Stay 4 Tha Night" is a song about being seduced by the devil and features some impressive synth fondling. The final, moody track, "Meet Me in the Forest", was used for the band's first foray into music video and animation, which became a large part of their work in the future. By April the band had realized they couldn't stay in the warehouse for a prolonged period of time and found a new headquarters at Electraplay Studios in Hilliard, Ohio.

The May EP sounds a bit like the band has spring fever. The production is brighter and bits of sunshine are beginning to peek through. The arrangements are lighter, too: the main instruments in these numbers are acoustic and electric piano and banjo. The first track is mysteriously titled "The Town Monster (Part Two)" and tells a story of an angel who comes to earth and warns the townspeople to repent...to which they promptly reply by burning him at the stake. By this point it is apparent that the band has grown comfortable taking risks with their music and their presentation of it, but also confident enough to write low-key, folk-inspired songs like the closing track "Onward", one of the best in their catalogue.

Definitely an oddball of the group, the June EP saw The Town Monster in a transitional period. This was to be the last they recorded with their excellent former bass player Mike Rana and he is featured heavily here, practically taking lead duties on the only instrumental song in the collection, "1 A.M.". This EP is deep, dark and groovy...syrupy, even. All three are tinged with hip hop beats and further experimentation with pitch-shifted and auto-tuned vocals. The closing track "Oil" was written the day after the historic BP oil spill and wound up being one of the band's angriest, most unique and most universal songs. It helps that it features fantastic lead guitar work by Rob Bradley of Sleepers Awake, as well as samples of the late Professor Longhair, a creole pioneer of rock and roll.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Town Monster/Ohio Sessions, April to June/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Town Monster/Ohio Sessions, April to June/cover_200.jpg

name: Ohio Sessions, January to March
description:
Ohio Sessions (January EP)
In the middle of snowy January 2010, The Town Monster announced on their MySpace page (yes, bands had those back then) that they would be putting out an EP on the last day of every month for the whole year. Shockingly, they did...and it's actually good.Recording and releasing a 44-song collection month by month month over the course of a year and in many locations would be a daunting task for any band. Nevertheless, while facing several lineup changes amidst relentless live performances, The Town Monster managed to churn out these bite-size albums one at a time, spanning numerous genres and managing to find their own particular sound in the process. The January EP begins with a brief acoustic tribute to their midwestern home before going straight into electropop territory. It ends with in icy piano ballad over glitched-out drum loops and orchestra samples, hinting at the numerous styles to come.

Ohio Sessions (February EP)
The February EP eventually became one of The Town Monster's most popular releases, and opening track "Raincloud" became a staple of their live show. On the remaining three tracks they begin toying with song structure and instrumentation, making use of 808s, banjos, pitch-shifted vocals, wind, rain, and samples from a song by the now-defunct Columbus band Burglar. "Birds and Bees are Natural Enemies" starts off almost sweetly, but the storm clouds make an ominous return, and by the end you are drowning in a flood of synthesizers. "Mongrel" is the band's best attempt yet at their own blend of mad circus rock. Although it serves the Ohio Sessions well, this EP stands out as a gem of its own.

Ohio Sessions (March EP)
March of 2010 saw the Monster in need of a new cave, and they temporarily found themselves in a dilapidated warehouse with no heat...and an EP to record if they were going to stay true to their word. According to the band, they could "see their breath during practice" and they would "record until their hands froze and they were forced to seek shelter". The recordings reflects the harsh conditions of their birthplace...they are abrasive and drenched in a metallic natural reverb from the giant open space they were taped in. Close listening reveals trains going by in the distance. The songs themselves are traditional/blues/hard rock at first glance, but the band's myriad influences still peek through with bits of melotron, destroyed keyboard, and ukulele. Vocally, this EP finds singer Nathan Photos becoming more comfortable in his own shoes, and these performances, which are mostly concerned with poverty and violence, sound scathing and desperate. This is Ohio rock at its finest.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Town Monster/Ohio Sessions, January to March/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Town Monster/Ohio Sessions, January to March/cover_200.jpg

name: Ohio Sessions, July to September
description:
Ohio Sessions (July EP) - Once again, the band did a 180 and released three songs featuring acoustic guitars and almost all major chords. It is bouncy and up-tempo, even featuring a song called "Summertime" that might be the closest they have yet come to straight-up pop music. The other two, "For Your Love" and "Why Does it Have to Hurt?" both come off sappy and sweet due to their Motown/traditional rock vibe, but the whole set are actually quite somber in their content. By the end you realize this is plastic, Lego sunshine and it can't possibly last. And in that sense, the band captured the fleeting beauty and the essence of Summer in the best way a (typically) dark electronic rock band possibly could.

Ohio Sessions (August EP) - Although this EP is a personal favorite of mine, there are arguably no "standout" tracks in this bunch. Instead, the band is more focused, quieter. You can finally begin to see them trying to adopt a "less is more" attitude, and the songs flow together quite well, despite the usual genre-hopping. "The Silver Thread" and "I Am The Forest Floor" (which feature the band's usual drummer Matt Grady on acoustic guitar) have a transcendent, otherworldly quality about them and frankly sound unlike any other band. Of course they bear resemblances to countless artists, but these songs, despite their flaws, are unmistakably and undeniably The Town Monster and no one else. The album closes with a gorgeous indie-style piano ballad that sounds like a tip of the hat to The Doves or The Autumns. It's a bittersweet kiss goodbye to the summer, and a surprising EP from a band full of surprises.

Ohio Sessions (September EP) September wound up becoming the most popular of the Ohio Sessions EPs and it's easy to see why. "One Thousand Wolves" became one of the band's most beloved songs, garnering heavy local radio play on CD102.5. "Dirty Little Secrets", with its cheesy church organ and steadily-picked bass could have been plucked straight from an 80's album if it weren't so strangely modern. This is music for vampires who also happen to love Bruce Springsteen. The closing track, "Pawn Shop", was the only song out of all 44 released during the Ohio Sessions that the band posted by itself on their Facebook page and said, "Listen to this one, it's good." Their first real venture into industrial music, it manages to feel like an old Sneaker Pimps or Massive Attack song with overdubs by Mars Volta and hints of, dare I say it...black metal? Whatever you want to call it, this was the point when people realized this band was not like other bands.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Town Monster/Ohio Sessions, July to September/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Town Monster/Ohio Sessions, July to September/cover_200.jpg

name: Ohio Sessions, October to December
description:
Ohio Sessions (October EP)
By now the boys seemed to have hit their stride, and they released this EP ahead of schedule so people could have it for Halloween, appropriately. It is commonly, mistakenly referred to as "The Halloween EP". These are the darkest songs in the collection, filled with lyrics about ghosts, possessed dolls, skeletons and witches and put to a soundtrack of smashed pianos, theremins, screaming, layers of shrieking guitars, thunderous drum machines crammed in the middle of real drums, and more screaming. This was the only EP the band recorded "live" in the studio, which even most non-musicians realize isn't very common nowadays. Although there are overdubs, it is apparent that it was recorded quickly and furiously. They can barely contain their energy, and it is most obvious at moments like the end of "Paper Boats, Paper Ghosts", which would almost sound like Black Sabbath if they weren't tripping over each other in their mania, or the climactic buildup toward the end of "B1G WH00P1N' 5K3L3T0N5 (I'm Not Guilty Anymore)" when all the disparate pieces finally come together in a lovely, relieving crescendo to let you know the nightmare is over.

Ohio Sessions (November EP)
It is the general consensus that the November EP left a lot of newcomers wondering if this was the still the same band from last month. Leaving all the neon lights and loud noises behind, they retreated back to pianos and banjos and released one of their most accomplished (and again one of their most understated) albums. With the exception of "The Glow" and its incessant drum machine, 90's guitar and Bjork-esque bells, these songs are gentler, more thoughtful, and more emotional. "The Coward" is one of their most mature works and proves there's some really good musicians buried under all those electronics. At this point, they sound like a band completely devoted to challenging themselves, and to constantly evolving.

Ohio Sessions (December EP)
When The Town Monster saw the finish line for this project, they knew they had to end it with a bang, and so they did...but not before they released a 25-minute animated Christmas special (yes, of course it's a musical!) in which they suffer the toils of being a local rock band, join a superhero group called The Shadow League of Rock and Roll Defenders of the World, and battle a dragon (of course). The December EP is a much more serious affair and is probably the best of the bunch. Yes, this is the same band it was twelve months ago, but their recordings became significantly more refined over that course of time, as did their songwriting, and it is a fascinating journey. After the sweeping eleven minute epic that is merely titled "(/)", the listener is left with what we now realize was the missing second half of "Ohio", the first song from the January EP. It is a touching moment as Photos starts listing off the things that "will always make his heart explode", and those things turn out to be a lot of the things he's been singing about all along. These twelve albums are not without the occasional misstep; indeed, many times it is the sound of a band trying something new and they don't have sure footing. You also get the feeling that, sometimes, they had a lot more work they wanted to do, but it was the end of the month, and it was time to move on. But it is this scrapbook quality that makes the Ohio Sessions a far more successful documentary of a band than a film could hope to be. As far as I'm aware, The Town Monster are the only artists that have done a project like this, and something magical was captured here. If every band worked this hard and took this many chances, the world would be a pretty different place.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Town Monster/Ohio Sessions, October to December/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Town Monster/Ohio Sessions, October to December/cover_200.jpg

name: Why we need Night
description: The Union Trade follow the contours of proven terrain and map the outlines of an evolving sound. In moments throughout, the band strips away the epic layers of their first album to expose the intimacy of a beautiful guitar line, the gravity of a simple piano progression, or the emotion and lyricism of a vocal performance. Energized by dynamic rhythms, the EP progresses from the familiar into new territory marked by a broader range of analog and acoustic keyboards, electronic elements and The Union Trade's most concise song structures to date. "Why We Need Night" captures The Union Trade as they continue to define the space where instrumental rock influences meet a more mainstream indie rock sound.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Union Trade/Why we need Night/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Union Trade/Why we need Night/cover_200.jpg

name: Extra Century Perception
description: The West Exit's third full-length release continues in their vein of smooth, soulful electro-pop. But the stylistic elements have become more magnified and mature on Extra Century Perception, with bigger beats, soaring melodies, thick harmonies, and more addictive hooks that will get your body moving.

name: Modern Interiors
description: Oh-so-debonair is the West Exit's latest album: a sleekly appealing blend of pop, jazz, and electronic influences. Urbane, subtly decadent dance grooves get warm touches of piano and acoustic guitar, bringing a friendly sense of soulfulness to the ultra-sophisticated pop. Perfect music for a cocktail party, driving around town, or in any other modern interior. Standout tracks include "Montreal," "The Long Count" and "Thirty Years."

name: Nocturne
description: Nocturne is a great album. It's got a great retro-disco feel, but on top of that it's just an unusually elegant work of pop? perfect harmonies, superb mood, and a fantastic ratio of dance-y/party energy to mellow, mid-tempo goodness. We've found that it's the absolute perfect thing to have on for a evening cocktails, because it keeps things the energy really up and buzzy without overwhelming anything. "Artificial" is one of the best tracks in the entire Magnatune catalog, and the entire album is just totally feel-good all around: positive, stylish, sexy, soulful.

name: Unearthed
description:
The West Exit's unique electro-soul sound is showcased like a pendulum on Unearthed. Starting out on the jazzy-soulful side, then swinging way off into the ambient electronic realm, back and forth until eventually landing in that sweet spot in the middle. The lyrical content spans everything from the usual suspects of love lost and love gained to the matters of religion, politics and the sad ballad of a broken hand drum.

Unearthed is a collection of b-sides and other unreleased music from The West Exit. The songs range from recordings done back in 2002 (when the band went by the name Dim At Asia) up to the non-album tracks from the Extra Century Perception album sessions in 2009. The diversity illustrates the evolution that the sound of The West Exit has undergone while still maintaining their knack for haunting melodies and addictive grooves.

name: Ambulatory
description: Ambulatory explores further what was started with Cyst: it's a super-smart hybrid of noisecore and drum'n'bass, with tons of texture and depth. Chilling noise-ambient opener "Admission" starts things off, after which we get into what appears the lightly rhythmic "Hope (living in stereo)," only to be ambushed mid-way through by an awesomely psychotic glitch-freakout. "Unrelax" is a great example of how well The Wretch blends atmospheric sounds with harder-edged ones, and the remix closer of "Alerting" has as huge, future-industrial sound. This genre can too often be mindless, but not The Wretch. The rhythms here are ultra-savvy and the sonic pallette, gigantic. They've got it going on.

name: Cyst
description: Fantastically dark, elegantly industrial, Cyst by The Wretch is a suprisingly nuanced album that favors dynamic variation over mindlessly repeated loops. It's a hybrid of noisecore and drum 'n'bass, but with really smart rhythms and a noise-ambient wash that lends a huge amount of atmosphere and depth. There's a really satisfying level of sonic texture on Cyst too; the juxtaposition of totally glitched out, ever-changing beats with the eerie ghost calls and dystopian waveforms in the background works really well. The opener "Turned" and "Do You" are great, "This is Terror" is beautifully brutal, and we absolutely love"Feel The Burning."

name: Cheat the Devil
description:
Pop culture has absorbed horror rock influences since the genre emerged in the post-punk ashes of the twentieth century. At the dawn of the new millennium, from their home hunting grounds of Philadelphia, the Young Werewolves unleashed their self-titled debut recording.

Now, after establishing an underground following and receiving favorable press from publications like MaximumRockNRoll and the Village Voice, the trio serve up their second sacrifice to all things horror and rock.

Cheat The Devil contains a set of thirteen tracks with a few surprises and a special guest star. Mad genius and ace producer Andy Kravitz once again presided over the sessions assuring a mysterious and spooky soundscape.

Cult film legend and executive producer, Sid Haig makes an appearance on Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde narrating the adapted text of Robert Louis Stevenson's classic. A wicked laugh track ensues, that you'd be hard pressed to find on any other record.

name: Cheat the Devil (Instrumental)
description:
Pop culture has absorbed horror rock influences since the genre emerged in the post-punk ashes of the twentieth century. At the dawn of the new millennium, from their home hunting grounds of Philadelphia, the Young Werewolves unleashed their self-titled debut recording.

Now, after establishing an underground following and receiving favorable press from publications like MaximumRockNRoll and the Village Voice, the trio serve up their second sacrifice to all things horror and rock.

Welcome to the instrumental version of their album Cheat The Devil which contains a set of thirteen tracks with a few surprises. Mad genius and ace producer Andy Kravitz once again presided over the sessions assuring a mysterious and spooky soundscape.

name: Sins of the Past
description:
While temptation, redemption and transformation always provided source material for the Philadelphia based trio, Sins of the Past creeps across new musical ground and showcases the bands quest for sonic exploration and songwriting maturity.

Twisting in new, unique ways, The Young Werewolves return to deform with Sins of the Past, their third studio recording and second on Magnatune.

The release follows the bands 2008 recording Cheat the Devil, produced by horror film star Sid Haig. In recent news, their music was featured on Showtime Television in their series "Shameless" starring William H. Macy.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Young Werewolves/Sins of the Past/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Young Werewolves/Sins of the Past/cover_200.jpg

name: Sins of the Past (Instrumental)
description:
Welcome to the instrumental version of The Young Werewolves' third studio album, Sins of the Past.

While temptation, redemption and transformation always provided source material for the Philadelphia based trio, SINS OF THE PAST creeps across new musical ground and showcases the bands quest for sonic exploration and songwriting maturity.

The release follows the bands 2008 recording CHEAT THE DEVIL, produced by horror film star Sid Haig. In recent news, their music was featured on SHOWTIME in their new series Shameless starring William H. Macy.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Young Werewolves/Sins of the Past (Instrumental)/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/The Young Werewolves/Sins of the Past (Instrumental)/cover_200.jpg

name: The Young Werewolves (Instrumental)
description:
Here is the instrumental version of the The Young Werewolves debut album.

Labeled rockabilly, psychobilly, punk, garage, surf and everything in between, the werewolves lurk along that phantom road, haunting in the shadows, screaming a sound that is at once retro and classic with equal swagger.

Horror themes are universal within rock music and it is in this tradition The Young Werewolves stake claim.

Percussionists and composers, Shewolf Dana Kain (bass), Jonny Wolf (drums) and Wolfman Nick Falcon (guitar), lay down solid time as good as any other ghouls out on the scene, or at least in their home hunting grounds of Philadelphia, PA.

These thirteen tracks bear testament. Recorded by ace engineer and producer Andy Kravitz (whose credits include The Rolling Stones, Taj Mahal, Billy Joel, Urge Overkill, Joan Osborne), The Young Werewolves, over the course of one weekend, clawed out these hook laden vamps about nocturnal love gone wrong and monsters getting mad.

name: The Young Werewolves
description:
Labeled rockabilly, psychobilly, punk, garage, surf and everything in between, "The Young Werewolves" lurk along that phantom road, haunting in the shadows, screaming a sound that is at once retro and classic with equal swagger.

Horror themes are universal within rock music and it is in the tradition the band stake claim.

Percussionists and composers, Shewolf Dana Kain (bass), Jonny Wolf (drums) and Wolfman Nick Falcon (guitar), lay down solid time and drop vocals as good as any other ghouls out on the scene, or at least in their home hunting grounds of Philadelphia, PA.

These thirteen tracks bear testament. Recorded by ace engineer and producer Andy Kravitz (whose credits include The Rolling Stones, Taj Mahal, Billy Joel, Urge Overkill, Joan Osborne), The Young Werewolves, over the course of one weekend, clawed out these hook laden vamps about nocturnal love gone wrong and monsters getting mad.

name: Singles (Instrumental)
description:
This is an all-instrumental version of the album Singles.

Thirty Day Notice's music is somewhere between pleasantly hypnotic and slightly disturbing in the rock/electronic genre. Lana and Joe (sister and brother) write, perform, mix and produce TDN in their solar powered recording studio in Fiji.

The feeling of their music is dark but sensual, earnest but alluring. Thirty Day Notice is an intimate experience. This is the instrumental version of their singles album, in order to hear the alluring lyrics please go to the vox version.

name: Singles
description:
Thirty Day Notice music is somewhere between pleasantly hypnotic and slightly disturbing in the rock/electronic genre. Lana and Joe (sister and brother) write, perform, mix and produce TDN in their solar powered recording studio in Fiji.

The feeling of their music is dark but sensual, earnest but alluring. The lyrics portray subject matters ranging from conspiracy, to the soul, from parallel universes, to consciousness, authentic love and the pursuit of more. Thirty Day Notice is an intimate experience.

name: Rare, the Kafi Kanada Sessions
description:
Kafi Kanada is a rare and ancient Indian classical raga. It provides the setting for this music in a "gravity-free environment," a melding of sitarist Jay Kishor's guitar playing with Savana Moore's piano.

There are so few of us left
and we are very old
we are the last of our kind
walking here
among our fallen ancestors
passing slowly
over their bones
like elephants in their mystical graveyards,
touching
ancient, mossy, weathered stones
discovering
the scent of our own coming absence
rising from the soil
and swallowed by the roses
still and pungent in the vaporous air
losing ourselves
in the moment of our own extinction
while we are not yet gone,
but merely rare

~Savana Moore

Cover photograph courtesy of Larry Shaefer
All music is live and improvised.

name: Transcend to Void
description:
This album includes 5 main tracks (Tamuke, Sokkan, Shingetsu, Choshi, Daha) composed mostly by unknown Fuke monks who played each piece during meditation.

After careful and repeated listening of these pieces, the spirit of each one reached deep into the soul of both listener and player, making it possible to imagine the various improvisations of bumblebee sound, ostinato, a simple melodic bass pattern matching the shakuhachi monody, like the early practices that appeared successively in the Western music history, going from modal structures to polyphony. The choice once made, gave rise to quite a natural voice, guided by the addition of bass lines while preserving the shakuhachi part in its entirety.

The voice is here utilized as an instrumentally, illustrating a quote from Rudolf Steiner: "The pure song should delete every word" In addition to the five main shakuhachi classics, other tracks are divided between improvisations, reappropriation and composition:

1. Tamuke "Ta" means hands, "Muke" means facing each other, or hands put together, which indicates solidarity within oneself and one's community. In solidarity we experience unity and in unity we experience transition and movement of energy from one body to another. This piece is played to commemorate the transition from one phase to another. It is also a eulogy and a requiem for the departed souls of loved ones. It is a melody that brings indescribable stillness deep into the heart.

2. While High - Improvisation

3. Sokkan - This piece can be translated as "breath-sight". It is played as a meditation and observation of the process of breathing the most essential human activity. When breath is observed, respected, and self-controlled, harmony and peace begin.

4. Transcend to Void - Improvisation

5. Shingetsu - "Shin" indicates the heart, the mind, and the spirit. "Getsu" indicates moon. The moon is symbolic of enlightenment and one's discovery of the truthful and sincere pathway in life. There is a certain level of effort that one must exert in order to cultivate, toil and refine diligently one's excellence and purity in mind, body, and spirit.

6. Secret - Improvisation

7. Tsukikusa - Improvisation

8. Choshi - "Cho" is refers to "searching", and "Shi" is refers to oneself. This piece is played to allow the player to tune to the instrument and the surrounding. It is the joining of Mind/Spirit/Instrument at the beginning of each meditation session.

9. Morning mist - Improvisation

10. Greensleevses - traditionnal English (Henry VIII)

11. Daha - "Da" means to tear apart, to break and to strike, "Ha" means wave. The striking waves along the seashores are a symbol of the infinite adversities that we need to overcome in our daily lives. Yet, the constant pounding of the waves along the sea rocks provides a constant process of cleansing and rejuvenation. Daha is played for the increased will power, humility, and determination to overcome those adversities. A peaceful dream

- Kyle Kamal Helou

name: First Album
description: If you're one of those people who thinks modern jazz is just inherently cheesy, check out the Thursday Group and see if they don't prove you wrong. Clayton Englar's sax playing alone would be worth the price of admission here (it's absolutely fantastic) but on top of that there's Doug Lichterman's subtly tight guitar work backed by exceptionally sensitive bass and foamy, atmospheric drums. This is one of those jazz ensembles that is just completely aware of one another at all times, plus they have an exceptionally artful sense of melody. It's their melodies in particular that make it clear that Thursday Group is not simply re-heating a bunch of jazz tropes; they're finding a musical path together. What they find is a sound that's deeply modern yet warm and accessible too. Really excellent, and 100 percent cheese free.

name: Uncle Mean
description: Avoiding both excess and cliche, Uncle Mean subtly blends jazz, funk, swing, and blues in a tasty, smoldering, brew. We really like Douglas Lichterman's cunning, sometimes island-y guitar work, and saxophonist Clayton Englar, is just fantastic. His playing is lean, husky, and modern. There's a reason this band has endured since the 1970's.

name: When the Fall
description: The tracks on this album transition easily from the dance floor to a movie score, channelling influences like Underworld, Aphex Twin, and William Orbit. Toronto composer Mark Aylward hooked up with engineer / producer James Miles on the latest Thursday Next sessions. A solid multi-instrumentalist, Aylward layers lush acoustic elements over broken beats with dramatic flair. Thursday Next is complex, cinematic, and cool. Just listen.

name: By The Way
description: Pared down and austere, popular Magnatune artist Tilopa's brand new album sounds like serenity itself. His Japanese zen flute (kyotaku) is occasionally accompanied by monastic sounding vocals, and the overall effect is very subdued, meditative. "Red Fullmoon" is a particular standout on this album, a track that makes evident why this type of music was once favored by sects of wandering Buddhist monks. Most of the pieces on this album have that same type of traditional, Zen sound, but there are a few more modern pieces here too, such as "Amigos De Viaje," which features acoustic guitar as accompaniment to the kyotaku.

name: Kyotaku Live
description: Atmospheric and timeless,Kyotaku Live showcases the richly serene sound of the kyotaku?an ancient Japanese zen-flute with pentatonic tuning. The kyotaku was played frequently in the old days of Japan, but was largely replaced by other instruments during the twentieth century. Reviving a nearly lost musical tradition, this recording by Tilopa features some of the most important traditional pieces for this instrument.

name: Out of the Blue
description: One of Tilopa's best-selling recordings, Out Of The Blue brings in a few modern touches to Tilopa's deeply Zen playing of the kyotaku. This time around there's some accompaniment on piano and other instruments, but it always stays true to Tilopa's pared down and deeply peaceful aesthetic. The album is primarily Eastern in sensibility, but there are some little cross cultural touches as well. We absolutely love, for instance, the blend of Spanish guitar and kyotaku in "El Corazon Canta." A wonderful album.

name: Pictures of Silence
description: Showcasing kyotaku in combination with other instruments, the contemplative Pictures of Silence shows Tilopa's preference for really resonant sounding instruments?the deeper, more mellow style of Japanese flute, a subtly rippling guitar, golden sounding koto... They're all in delicate correspondence with one another on this album, yet adhere to Tilopa's beautifully minimal, meditative aesthetic. A crystal clear recording makes you feel like the musicians are performing right there in the room.

name: Turkishauch
description: Completely and utterly Zen-ed out, Turkishauch is as meditative as music gets. It features master of the Japanese flute, Tilopa, who plays the shakuhachi?and Japanese flute that has a pentatonic tuning and a much deeper and more mellow sound than other Japanese flutes. His playing isn't so much performance as it is meditative practice, so it's deep and cosmic and peaceful and totally gorgeous. Highly recommended.

name: Unravelling
description:
These improvisations are the result of an unusual meeting between East and West, Japanese zenflute and piano. A meeting in the unknown that again and again surprises the listener (as much as the musicians themselves) through its' many different facets. A story unravelling in wide open space told by two masters of their instruments with silence as its main character and permeated by their deep joy in music.

Aki Hoffman, a teacher of piano and especially the art of improvisation at different european universities, is the perfect match for Tilopa with his sound training in traditional Zen music and his fascination with crossover projects since years.

name: Aksaray
description: A collection of pieces in Turkish, Persian, and Sephardic folk styles, written and recorded by Tim at various points over the last seven years, either never released or being re-released now. Featuring Tim playing saz, 'ud, sehtar, tar, tamboor, santur, psaltery, and percussion.

name: Ashek
description: On Ashek hyper-gifted multi-instrumentalist Tim Rabyorn brings to life the music of worldly and spiritual love from Greece, the Middle East, and Central Asia. The album features both vocal and instrumental music spanning several centuries and thousands of miles, but united by one common theme: the longing for true love-whether physical or spiritual. The album's title derives from the "ashiklar," a unique group of traveling Turkish bards whose name means those who are "in love" with God, and the album really reflects this longing for union with the devine, and far from being sentimental, contains some of the most mysterious and somber works in Rayborn's entire catalog. Typically gorgeous work from a world-class talent in the field of ancient music.

name: Chordae
description: Reviving the tradition of medieval musical improvisation,Chordae comes across as music for its own sake, featuring beautiful melodies played on historic instruments by the gifted musicianTim Rayborn. In addition to being a performer, Tim is also a scholar of medieval cultures, so for this album he extrapolated specific playing techniques from illuminated medieval manuscripts and surviving European folk music practices. The strings are played with the nails, for instance, which makes for a more crisp and defined sound. A deeply melodic and authentic album, and an ideal one to have on in the background while working or studying.

name: Honey From The Thorn
description:
A collection of songs, dances, devotional pieces, and instrumental realizations from medieval England, encompassing the 12th through the early 14th centuries.

Despite much damage done to the manuscript sources, and much music being lost, what little medieval English music that does survive gives us a rare and precious glimpse into what must have been a vibrant musical culture.

On this recording, medieval scholar and musician Tim Rayborn presents some of this variety on reconstructions of medieval instruments, as well as with the voice. Joined by the prodigious musical talents of Annette Bauer, Phoebe Jevtovic, Shira Kammen, and Susan Rode Morris, this recording captures the spirit of a time long past.

Tim Rayborn: voice, harp, psaltery, percussion, lute, symphonie

With:
Annette Bauer: recorders, voice
Phoebe Jevtovic: voice
Shira Kammen: vielle, harp
Susan Rose Morris: voice

name: The Path Beyond
description: "Music from the edges of Islamic civilization," is how the incredibly talented multi-instrumentalist Tim Rayborn describes The Path Beyond, an assortment of Jewish, Christian, and Islamic instrumental music from medieval Spain, North Africa, Turkey, Iran, and the Balkans. This decidedly pre-modern has a gloriously acoustic sound. Tim, and will transport you not only to other worlds, but to another time within those worlds. Tim is known for his exceptionally great production values and attention to detail, so his music has this clean yet warm, sensual sound that falls very gracefully on the ears. Five of these songs are of historical and traditional origin, while the others are improvisations or compositions that "reflect the spirit of ancient heritage." Simply great. Pick it up today.

name: Qadim
description: On Qadim, the amazing multi-instrumentalist Tim Rayborn is exploring the art of performance by a solo instrument-an art form that has a long and honored tradition in the Arabic world. The intimate focus of a single source of music provides a distinctly non-Western listening experience; the word "Qadim," in fact, is an Arabic one referring to music performed in an "old style", and according to traditional concepts. Two of the works here are among the oldest known written music: two songs from Ancient Greece invoke the muses, and there's a 3,500-year-old hymn to the Babylonian moon goddess Nikkal. Beautiful work, as usual, from the deeply talented Tim Rayborn.

name: Rihla
description: Put this on and your immediate environs will instantly turn into a suradeq stuffed with silk pillows, Kilim rugs, and fig-laden platters. Featuring Tim Rayborn's ultra-precise musical talents, and some outstanding vocal tracks, Rihla is everything we best love about this performer: deep fluency in Middle Eastern music, incredibly detailed performances, and a 100 percent acoustic aesthetic.

name: The Three Noble Strains
description: In ancient Irish lore, the Three Noble Strains were three styles of playing the harp. They were drawn from the story of Boann, who gave birth to three sons. The eldest, Goltraiges, was born in great pain to her. The second, Gentraiges, was born with joy. The birth of the third, Suantres, caused her great fatigue. These boys grew up to become master harpers and their styles, or strains, were said to be derived from the manner of their birth: the goltrai (the strain of weeping), the geantrai (the strain of happiness), and the suantrai (the strain of sleep). It was these styles which harpers were expected to master and invoke in their audiences.

name: Veils of Light
description: Dance and music predate civilization, and as a musician, Tim Rayborn's mission is to explore our human resonance with rhythm. Veils Of Lightcertainly accomplishes that; it seamlessly gildes in and out of a range of cultures and civilizations including Balkans, the Middle East, and Central Asia, and features the fantastically detailed drum and string work of this incredibly talented multi-instrumentalist. The acoustic aesthetic and crystal clear production values on Veils of Light bestow a beautifully subtle sultriness to it; Tim seems to understand that because his compositions are so highly patterned and vibrant, there's no need to overstate the case. And in an era of hyped-up Hollywood glamour, this distinctly authentic exoticism is a very welcome thing. Check this one out today.

name: Bootstrap Physics
description:
The viola da gamba, primarily found in music of the Renaissance and Baroque, is here used in varying combinations with electric guitar, synthesizer, acoustic guitar, and medieval fiddle. The musical style organically blends old with new, classical with popular. The result is a richly textured, expressive music with a sound all its own.

"Bootstrap Physics" explores a musical compatibility between instruments and styles that aren't often combined.

"Vajda plays all the instruments and writes all the tunes on this instrumental album, and it is really compelling. His primary instrument is the viola da gamba, which looks like a cello, plays like a cello ? but it's a viola. Regardless of my ignorance on that topic, I can still appreciate the beauty of this music. Soothing, intriguing and different enough to make it stand out."
- Toledo City Paper

name: Idea of Alice
description:
Jangly relaxed alt rock, perfect for the grey days where you don't *want* to feel up and happy, but instead settle into self-indulgent melancholia.

Singer Cameron Ember contributed these thoughts about the album:

Can't remember what I was thinking but found myself on the way to the refrigerator
can't talk and drive at the same time
sadness like an epileptic seizure
mind automatic as a popular ski run
imagine I was somebody else, like an Olympic athlete
vivid dreams about smells, like a body down the garbage disposal
and the bedroom does not smell great when I wake up in reality
words skimmed from the screen like leaves raked from the yard in Autumn
I remember feelings, not places, faces, names, times, events, conversations or facts

Tiny little blackouts.. lose yourself for a moment.

name: A New Age Has Begun
description:
To Life! begins where other trancey world music groups leave off. Besides the musicianship honed from deepening the grooves over years of experience, the immeasurable passion of this trio takes the listener on a magic carpet of cross-cultural discovery of what lies inside the mystery.

In this second album, "A New Age Has Begun", To Life! once again uncovers some of the deepest grooves from around the planet, mixing it up in their highly identifiable, unique, and infectious style, while bringing a positive perspective on these changing times.....
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/To Life!/A New Age Has Begun/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/To Life!/A New Age Has Begun/cover_200.jpg

name: Tasabasaba
description: TASABASABA fuses North African, Middle Eastern, and contemporary grooves to create a unique and compelling trance music genre like no one else. "Funky World Global" has been used to describe the sound, although one might want to add 'tribal', 'organic', and 'soulful' to the mix! African djun djuns and aboriginal didjeridoo drive the primal rhythm, made contemporary by this fresh California group. This is the first full-length release from the Bay Area World Music Trio "To Life!"

name: Futureshock
description: This album was shelved for two years and then, when Anatoly moved to live in Moscow he found out that original source files of the album were lost or corrupted. Only a couple of months ago while digging through his old hardware he found a broken hard disk with the original files. After hours of hard work and violent warfare with broken clusters and software compatibility he finally resurrected this long lost work and today it finally sees the light as a two-part album Futureshock.

name: Plus
description:
Take it easy on the caffeine and put the cat out... "Plus", the debut album of Anatoly Grinberg (Tokee) is a chemical journey through electro/IDM, rave and industrial from a satisfyingly dark electronic and technoid angle. A dark world of drug-fueled visions which takes us on an emotional soundtrack to a science-fiction movie, a blending of mechanical and organic worlds, depressive, sad and cyberpunky.

Each track pulls us through a swath of visions and emotions. From the tough, rugged break-beats of "Th" which evolves through soaring atmospheres into a trance/industrial epic, to the plaintive keystrokes on "Pa", which compliment the bottom-heavy flow nicely. Hardcore returns with "No" and "Np" and then morphs into the funky clicks and chirps of "Pu". An introspective, rainy day ambiance of "Am", descends to the seething dark-rave of "Bk". "Cf" climbs to happy hardcore territory, before grabbing your guts for a booming and vital, "Fm" which transforms into archetypical dark-rave once its own break-beat pacing cuts in. The album ends with tracks lilting to the more ambient side of Tokee such as the ominous and spiritual "Md" and then the ethereal, badly hallucinogenic "Lr". We warned you...

name: Quintuplet
description: Fascinated with various currencies of electronic music and inspired by dinosaurs like Kraftwerk, Depeche Mode, Skinny Puppy, Can etc, Tokee's latest efforts combine tight mechanical-sounding IDM and industrial beats, cinematic-like ambient themes, psychotic trance shockwaves, evolving into incredible melodic soundscapes both aggressive and melancholic. It's an untamed animal, at times wild and fiery and others reclusive and emotional. Listening to "Quintuplet" is like a drive on a crazy carousel - which turns faster and faster. Inspiring music made in a genius way.

name: Tokyo507 Instrumental
description:
This is an instrumental release from Tokyo507. It features many of the tracks from the previous Tokyo507 album (also available on Magnatune) as instrumentals and 3 new tracks.

All of the tracks are Chillout, Downtempo and Jazzy in style.

name: When I Cross The River
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Tom Bolton/When I Cross The River/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Tom Bolton/When I Cross The River/cover_200.jpg

name: Dreaming and Dancing
description:
Dreaming and Dancing is the latest collection of folk-rock/pop songs coming out of Tom Bolton's long strange journey into music. The dreams are all that we hope for: emotionally, sensually, socially, politically? our aspirations and longings. The dancing is what we do to enact and celebrate these aspirations and longings, and to express delight in their fulfillment or pain in their frustration.

The collaboration between Tom and Nick Charles (the producer) was a leisurely, considerate, respectful conversation... but nonetheless an adventurous one that allowed the arrangements to fly off to wherever it was that the musicians' instincts took them. The musicians came into the studio unsuspecting, not knowing the material at all, from a variety of folk, roots, jazz, rock, pop and classical backgrounds.

There was no plan, only an unfolding of the previously undiscovered, until the album became what it is. At a certain point, as the title track indicates, all the talking is done and the time for words is over. Shall we dance? Let's dance!

name: Borrowed Time
description:
Tom Paul is back with a new album offering entitled "Borrowed Time". Tom produced this album himself. However he retained Charlie Morgan who played drums on his first 2 albums. The result is a more direct "guitar rock" presentation. Tom wrote these songs about personal hardship and the growth that he found through the experience of being unemployed in 2008. Everyone will find themselves humming these tunes after a couple of listens.

Tom's musicianship and vocals have continued to mature since his last release "There is no map" in 2003. This album, like his previous works, is a celebration of life made more poignant by facing down his own demons. Tom was told early on that to write great songs you just need a 3 chords and the truth. This album challenges us to take an honest look at our own lives....the rewards can be wonderful.

name: Empty Man
description:
You'd expect to hear these songs on the radio while driving along through some parallel universe. Each of the songs on Tom Paul's newest release, "Empty Man" is recognizable yet still original. The hooks grab you and pull you into something familiar and warm. You'll find yourself singing along to songs that feel something like Bob Dylan, The Beatles, or maybe Tom Petty. His lyrics are honest and expressive. They join perfectly with the music to take you into Tom's world. It's a world where you can relax with your mate on a sunny afternoon in the park, or risk everything for love. It's also a world where our obsessions and compulsions can have us tossing and turning at night looking for a way out of a mess. But even in the worst days, we sense that Tom believes there is the possibility of redemption if we are only will to try.

Tom teams up with drummer Charlie Morgan to present tight pop-rock numbers. His friend, Ralph Edgar, contributed lyrics to the song about a Monongahela River Barge called the "Annie B Wilson". Danie Paul, his son, sang harmonies on "Eagle over 79" which is about a real life experience of seeing Bald Eagles returning to Tom's native Western Pennsylvania. Otherwise, Tom plays all the instruments, sang, and mixed the album himself in 2011 and 2012.

name: I Was King
description: Melodic and accessible,I Was King is great singer-songwriter fare in the tradition of David Grey and John Hiatt, with a touch of Tom Petty's influence. It's warm, personal, and in Tom Paul's case, pretty darn easy going. "It's an Easy Life" opens the album, and manages to be intensely optimistic without being the least bit cloying. This album will make you feel good, in other words, which is a nice way to feel: dontcha think? "Highly hummable," says one listener.

name: There is no map
description: Tom Paul's second full length album There Is No Map begins with his characteristic optimism, laced with the slight edge of Messrs. Dylan and Petty's influence. Tom again called on Charlie Morgan [Elton John, Paul McCartney, Thin Lizzie] to supply drums, and Charlie DeChant [Hall ? Oates? sits in on saxaphone for two tracks, including "She's My Girlfriend," which is a super catchy track. "I Saw A Rainbow" is a standout as well. It's a ballad about an everyday event can salvage even the worst day, and it's a good example of Tom's preference as an artist for exploring every day events and challenges. "Physical Girl" rips it up in a roots rock fashion, and "Hey now, Babus" (about Tom's daughter) is everyone's favorite for it's tender, good time vibe.

name: La Manana de San Juan
description: Tomas Lozano takes you on a journey through centuries-old musical Spain by way of ballads about knights, kings, princesses, shepherds, maidens, sailors, millers and death. This is the nine hundred year old tradition of the Spanish "Romancero". Lozano mesmerizes audiences with his voice in accompaniment of spanish acoustic guitar and hurdy-gurdy.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Tomas Lozano/La Manana de San Juan/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Tomas Lozano/La Manana de San Juan/cover_200.jpg

name: Fading Blue
description:
A catchy, laid back sounding album which blends acoustic, electric instruments and vocal harmonies which move from folk, to rock and into pop genres.

The songs are built around strong emotive lyrics, hooky sounding verses and big choruses. Lyrically the songs deal with someone trying to find their place in the world and the ups and downs that a search like that brings.

Fading Blue is Tonethief's debut album.

name: Creation
description:
Creation contains Momo's new operatic works, recorded in collaboration with American soprano Rebecca Nelsen and British countertenors Richard Scott and Oliver Gerrish at the Royal College of Music and Cavendish Studios in London.

The album was originally going to be named ACGT, denoting the "A", "C", "G" and "T" nucleic acids that make up a creature's genetic code or DNA. This album is the result of my quest for understanding human nature, the origin of the species, basically the human species.

Science tells us that for humans, sex is the origin of mortality, because rather than reproducing clonally as bacteria do, we only transmit half our genes to our offspring, and they will never naturally exist in the same combination again. Different combinations of ACGT's make us unique, completely unique.

"Creation" therefore revolves about the miracle of human life, wondering the roles of creation and evolution in explaining the hows and whys of this miracle.

name: Motherland
description:
"Motherland" contains my recent collaborations with a large number of exquisite pop singers such as Roberta Howett, Beth Rodergas, Michela Magas, Jojo Desmond, Jude La Joia, Michelle and Nesha.

"Motherland" is a homage to that space we call home. All of these songs have been written away from my motherland which is Spain, and most importantly maybe away from this home I'm trying to find through this long and tortuous journey of mine. Our Motherland makes us strong and makes us aware of the power inherent in us as human beings. Being away from it makes life more difficult.

The songs reflect on my life experiences away from my Motherland and are a homage to all those people around the world that live away from theirs.

name: Unharmed
description:
Unharmed: Unharmed was conceived between 2004 and 2007 in London. It deals with Toni's start of a new life in a new land and the heightened uncertainty of human condition he experienced. His constant struggle to understand the meaning of life as such, and how he discovers that love is the only thing that brings meaning to his existence.

Toni met Spanish star singer Beth Rodergas during this time, her becoming the voice of some of the most iconic songs in the album. Irish wonder Roberta Howett, jazz jewell Gracie Patton and New Zealander soprano Amelia Whiteman also added their unique voices to this album. Beau, the most special track in the album, was created in conjunction with artist Michela Magas, who wrote the lyric and melody of lead singer.

The album was released digitally in 2007 and soon reached the iTunes Top 20 download charts. It was released in 2008 in physical format under the Instant Attraction independent label. It now sells over 15 different countries having created an established and heterogeneous fan-base defying genres, styles and trends.

name: Rain Trip
description:
In his album Rain Trip, the compositions relate to the hard journey of rain. It's a journey into the emotions of the author put into direct contact with forests, rivers, mountains and lakes. Toni Iniguez, attempts to express and show the maximum beauty that is capable from the strings of the Spanish classical guitar and its sounds, made in a modern language, with touches of folk, jazz and classical music.

Thus are born songs such as sensations produced by the smells of the wet earth after rain, sounds made with the exceptional talents of violinist Lucia Marin (with whom he has worked for many years). On the song cloud, Toni Iniguez flies over the tops of trees in a forest and he pays tribute the great master Johann Sebastian Bach, arranging his cantata and transforming the final into a primal ethereal beat. The album follows rain as you would hear, feel and smell following a dawn looking through the window to the distant mountains.

name: The Garden
description:
Immerse yourself in the surround sounds, and quiet, minimalist rhythms of "The Garden". Innovative work in structure and sound, designed without considering gender. The songs and melodies contained in this album are made with textures of 6 and 12 classical guitars superimposed, creating organic shapes, and arranged in a rhythmic mix / original melodic.

The album was composed around the idea of meditation, silence and the beautiful sound of the classical guitar. The songs are arranged carefully to create a sense of silent meditation. The power and intensity of the pieces moving more in the middle of the album suggest we lost in the intoxicating sounds of The Garden.

The idea for this project was to create an organic blend of hypnotic sounds of meditative and minimalist music with the most beautiful instrument that exists: the classical guitar. Enter The Garden and observe life around you. You've never heard anything like it. The music of The Garden you will absorb and marvel.

name: The Instrumental Collection
description:
Torn Down Units play a unique mix of Rock n' Roll, Punk, Surf, and Rockabilly music. TDU's mandate is to keep the fires of rock n' roll burning hotter than ever in an age where the only music getting attention (be it positive or negative) is conceived in a board room, not a jam space, and is void of any wit, charm or substance.

Faced with this grim reality, TDU offers an alternative, designed for people who still believe in the power of rock n' roll. Enjoy this collection of the best of Torn Down Units instrumental tracks. A whole new kind of instrumental rock.

name: A Collection of Quality Rock and Roll
description:
Torn Down Units play a unique mix of Rock n' Roll, Punk, Surf, and Rockabilly music.

TDU's mandate is to keep the fires of rock n' roll burning hotter than ever in an age where the only music getting attention (be it positive or negative) is conceived in a board room, not a jam space, and is void of any wit, charm or substance. Faced with this grim reality, TDU offers an alternative, designed for people who still believe in the power of rock n' roll. Enjoy this collection of the best of Torn Down Units.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Torn Down Units/A Collection of Quality Rock and Roll/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Torn Down Units/A Collection of Quality Rock and Roll/cover_200.jpg

name: Eight
description:
Each song on this album falls into a separate or hybrid genre that retains its identity as dark ambient. The album is a representation of the variation of emotion and its wide range of effects. The album begins somberly and slowly while ending anxiously, out of breath. From the highs of happiness and the wayward lows, you'll be slowly transported between different emotions from each of the eight songs.

Eight is my first release and is a collection of songs with a sense of continuity as well as an introduction to my music and personality. These songs are my eight best, all maintaining common expression and emotion.

name: Lemuria
description: With gorgeously atmospheric selections ranging from chill-out to ambient to techno, Lemuria showcases Trancevision's ability to create entire worlds within songs: big, beautiful sonic landscapes that swirl and glimmer and billow beguilingly. Singer Greta Rose's voice sounds fantastic; she and Pete Code are good at exploring the overlap between ancient and contemporary music without kowtowing to trends in this area. Everything on Lemuria is original, and the sound one that hinges on a modern understanding of both musicianship and mood. Features guest musicians Kip Winger (Winger, Alan Parsons) on fretless bass on "Lemuria", as well as Tim Reynolds (TR3) on rhythm ? lead guitar for "Atom" and "Enertia."

name: Airs De Cour Francais Du XVIIe Siecle
description: With coherence of style and great creativity in ornamentation, the three women of the Trio Dafne perform the airs de cour of the 17th century with all-original instrumentation, and the result is delicately beautiful album of French chanson, with the intimate feeling of a parlor room recital.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Trio Dafne/Airs De Cour Francais Du XVIIe Siecle/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Trio Dafne/Airs De Cour Francais Du XVIIe Siecle/cover_200.jpg

name: Curve
description: Rich litle melodies and gentle harmonies make for a soothing album of instrumental bass guitar by the capable Trip Wamsley. Wamsley has a patient sense of timing, allowing his music to unfold gracefully and on its own time. Says one reviewer, "this album is a quest through mood, tone, timbre, texture," and as the album title suggests, Curve is completely without any sharp angels. Instead, it's as polished and graceful as an old cherry wood banister.

name: Its Better This Way
description: With its warm, rich tones and easygoing vibe, the instrumental It's Better This Way is Trip Wamsley's most accessible and polished work to date, and is an excellent show of his ability to use the bass guitar as a complete orchestra. Right hand, left hand, all ten fingers, tuning keys-every ounce of the bass guitar's potential is used. Musicains will appreciate his creative use of both fretted and fretless basses, as well as special effects, and detuners. It's Better This Way was recorded in Nashville with producer Todd Bragg (Caedmon's Call). A very artisanal album, crafted by a talented purist.

name: Giallo
description:
Giallo reflects influences of all of my favorite music, filtered through my own unique world view and style. With influences ranging from Tom Waits to Gwen Stefani, the Beatles to Busta Rhymes, Led Zeppelin to Bjork, my music manages to hint at all of my favorite styles while still sounding completely new and original.

While my earlier music was primarily about experimentation and finding strange and unique sounds with a number of instruments, this new album reflects a more focused vision. The "anything goes" nature of the music is intact while still appealing to the straightforward bubblegum pop lover in us all.

These songs are like time travelers, picking up the best bits of pop from each decade and maybe even a little bit of the future. With the help of producer Giles Reaves, I have put together an album of songs that will take you on a crazy musical carnival ride. With sunshine guitars, sing-along lyrics, hypnotic electronics and dance floor beats, this album is designed to make you feel like a kid going through your cool older siblings record collection for the first time.

name: Piano Works
description:
The pieces on "Piano Works" range from very simple and easy-to-play pieces, such as the "three birds", to overly extensive works with complex progression written for 2 pianos which would be the "Progredium". The same goes for the influences. You can sense a bit of a tango atmosphere when listening to "Black Elegance", or you might prefer to follow the contemporary development of "Tribute to Braid" which was inspired by the soundtrack of the video game "Braid". Basically jazz and modern classical music play a major role when it comes to the influences of this album, although they have rather been carefully separated instead of mixed together.

Piano Works is not what you might expect. Some of you might notice that the pieces don't really sound like a piano that has been recorded directly. This is an album that has almost completely been composed with one finger instead of ten. Of course, the sounds you hear do come from a real piano, although the composer of this album has never even seen this piano before. Additionally, the 'notes' do not even look like real notes, although digital composing software that allows one to create a score is widely available and works well, but in this case the notes are simply bars of different length with an associated 'velocity value', and yes, every single track has been created by drawing bars with a mouse. There is no solid style that has been maintained throughout the whole collection.

name: Goin' My Way
description:
Rhythm and Blues, Soul musician Ty Gibson has been added to the ever evolving sea of lyrical musicians looking to make a difference with her debut album, Goin' My Way. Ty offers her listeners a taste of what's on the inside of all of us, a passion to live, love and just be taken seriously.

With songs like, "Love Sweet Love" and "All You Need" for starters, Ty is conveying to a world that is somewhat void of these essential ingredients what it needs to help it get on with the healing and living.

With interest being sparked in Japan, The UK and Australia, Ty has set her sights on a global invasion of mind boggling proportions allowing ample ammunition to impact her world with her infectious sound.

"I'll Be Home Soon" was a song that was written with the men and women in the military in mind. Ty is actually singing a letter that a soldier has written to his loved one back home.

"I was excited when I got to do a tour in Korea for the Military, I felt it was the perfect time to pen a song that expressed my appreciation to them for giving up their freedom so that I and so many others can hang on to ours.".. Ty

In a nutshell, Ty Gibson is a force you must reckon with because she is will be around for a long time, her thoughts will be heard worldwide and with mass appeal, you will visualize the universal success of... TY GIBSON.

name: Un-Kai
description:
We're very glad to present to you this debut-album of Un-Kai. Literally meaning "sea of clouds" in Japanese, the music represents a new, fresh approach in sound design.

The concept behind Un-Kai is to integrate percussion and electronic music as closely as possible. Not just two layers, an electronic beat with percussion played over it, for example, but the sounds had to blend together in a more organic way. We tried to do so by using all kinds of technical trickery like triggering a vocoder by a Bendir (percussion instrument) or using a convolution sample of a Tabla (instead of a reverb sample) over a drum computer loop. But now we're getting too technical :-) Maybe more importantly than the above, it had to be danceable and an adventure to listen to!

Chill out on organic percussive beats, relax on various oriental atmospheres and immerse yourself into this unique sound adventure!

name: Conduct Unbecoming
description:
Uncle Pooch releases its debut album "Conduct Unbecoming" on Magnatune.

Mixed and mastered by Kevin Jenkins (The West Exit) this full-length album includes guest appearances by vocalist Kimo Muraki (17th Chapter) and guitarist RL Heyer (RL Heyer Trio, Flowmotion). It features the Naked City-esque track "Assault ? Battery Acid", the epic middle-eastern slammer, "Fallujah" and the bone crushing "Shame Spiral" which in the end is swallowed by a swamp of feedback and thousands of strange little critters.

Conduct Unbecoming is not for the faint of heart. Its twisted melodies are accompanied by face-melting riffs and ferocious improvisations. This is a groundbreaking album by a metal band that has dared to cross genres and erase boundary lines forever expanding its musical playground.

name: A Origem da Natureza Urbana
description: Urban Response's debut album "A Origem da Natureza Urbana" (The Origins of Urban Nature) is a funky and upbeat blend of styles, a meeting of different cultures and colors. A celebration of the best of both hemispheres, north and south. A six track labour of love by Irish producer Elektrodouche and Brazilian vocalist MC Quilombola. A Origem da Natureza Urbana is an honest and well crafted album with intelligent lyrics and funky tropical vibes. Traveling through trip-hop, electro, dub, classic hip-hop and funk along the way, the album is a journey through all their influences. It's the perfect soundtrack for your summer.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Urban Response/A Origem da Natureza Urbana/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Urban Response/A Origem da Natureza Urbana/cover_200.jpg

name: Soundtrack Without Movie
description:
The debut Album "Soundtrack without movie" is a result of two-years' work and long searching. What does the musician search: he searches for a sense of his creativity. Why is the music necessary? To whom is it intended?

"Soundtrack without movie" is Ustoz's first attempt to answer these questions. "This album is for those who wish to think whilst listening to the music. To reflect on the meaning of their life, to think about their own place in this world and to understand 'what is happiness'. I set these questions to myself whilst working on this album. I think this album, will be a fine background (soundtrack) for reflections about life."

It is the citation which defines the album's name. After all, our life is - as cinema, is one which always needs a soundtrack.

name: Night of the Black Wyvern
description: Magnatune best seller, Night of The Black Wyvern is death metal as it should be: super dark and super precise. Strongly influenced by Swedish death metal gods At The Gates, Dissection, and Amon Amarth, Utopia Banished more than hold its own with machine gun drums from Nick Tumia, angular, biting guitar work from Ian Scott, and ragged, wrathful vocals from Danny Augugliaro. If you're into Scandinavian death metal, definitely check these guys out.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Utopia Banished/Night of the Black Wyvern/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Utopia Banished/Night of the Black Wyvern/cover_200.jpg

name: Cachonda
description:
Cachonda and Cachonda (Foreplay), together with Diablo and Por debajo del Agua were done originally for the videohome Cumbia cachonda from director Christian Gonzalez. Patria / Extranjero and Stravinsky appear in their original version in the album Volk. "Cachonda" means horny and/or sexy in Mexico.

Review
"Here is another excellent album of Nortec electronica from Mexican sound artist Vate. I understand Vate is currently living in Barcelona. It may be my imagination but I could swear I'm hearing a little European and Spanish influences leaking into his electronic compositions. What is clear is that he still makes highly listenable state-of-the-art music.

Cachonda is his newest release and the tracks, both originals and remixes, are more developed and reveals a highly individualized style. "Diablo" is an especially nice work, being very atmospheric and distinctive. "Extranjero (Sin patria)" is snappy and dancable. Most of these track falls firmly into Nortec but "Stravinsky (Variaciones)" hints of that turn to European influences I mentioned. All in all, Vate has become one of my favorite independent artists in this particular genre."

Check out Cachonda on Youtube.

name: Exotica
description:
Exotica is a momentary comeback to the electronic cumbia genre. Exotica and Excentrica are two tracks made originally for the documentary "Los exoticos" by Michael Ramos Araizaga.

Both combine, as in the Cachonda album, the sound of cumbia with electronic music. Porno Vector y Spexie complement the EP with a more techno sound.

Cover art by Guillermo Ariete.

name: Umbra
description:
This album is the soundtrack for the film "Sombras" by Galo Tobias. The themes are on a dark ambient tone and focus on improvisation.

Umbra is the follow up album of Vitam. Some of the tracks are reconstructions and adaptations of themes taken from previous albums by Vate. Cover design by Vate, Minuit de Lacroix, and Galo Tobias.

name: Vitam
description:
The tracks on this album have several influences, from ambient, techno, drum and bass, and even some nods at dubstep.

Vitam is a walk through the stages of life: to be born, to grow, to live together, to consume, to inhabit, to eat, to love, and to die. After 4 years of intermittent releases and participations on some compilations, Vate returns with a new full-length album: Vitam.

name: Volt
description:
Volt is a trip trough the electro, IDM mixed with a bit of experimental.

Reviews:
"This release from Vate is really top notch stuff. I dont know if its just cause I have been out of contact for a while, but this really just hit the right note with me. The first track (Turismo) is just really trippy and really reminds me of the trancy stuff from the early 90's with a 2007 overhaul. The second track (Orient Stress), which is also featured on the previous release from Vate, has a pulsating tribal rhythm with growling basslines set to a slamming breakbeat. Almost industrial in some aspects. These billowing basslines continue through to the next track which is also a standout track. Hertz drops into a more minimal-IDM style and it slowly progresses into more distorted IDM sounds from here onward. Overall the album is fantastic and its highly recommended. Even if its just for the first few tracks as not all of them will appeal to everyone."
Net-label review blog

name: Versions
description: Recorded by a particularly grassy grass-roots collective of progressive musicians and engineers Versions is all about atmosphere, so it's a great album to have on in the background while you do other things. Mellow and soulful, it judiciously uses its dub and reggae influences to create a mid-tempo sound that's a pitch perfect blend of relaxing and energizing qualities. We especially love "Double Trust," "Universal Humans," and the delightfully ramshackle "Love Redux." Put this one in your "wallpaper" mix and smoke it.

name: Night Light
description:
I remember these Scandinavian lullabies from growing up in Norway, but singing them now gives me an experience of how the depth of darkness and the clarity of light can exist at the same time in one song. And in this way it reflects what is so much a part of the northern countries, - light and darkness that show up in such extreme ways.

The songs have brought these two opposites together for me, letting our dark and light sides exist in the same space, through the tenderness of the lullabye. I hope you will have your own unique experience as you listen to these songs from the land where the days are dark and the nights are light.

name: Solo cello works by JS Bach, CPE Bach, Biber and Paternoster
description:
As Bach emphasized in his own Six Suites for Unaccompanied Cello, the practice of cello solo combines different meanings: monody and polyphony, tonality and modality, the ancient and the modern.

Vito Paternoster's cello is like an expressive universe which doesn't need any accompaniment. It is a great challenge to pull this off.

J.S. Bach, Partita in D minor - this piece represents the transcription for cello of the renowned Partita in A minor for flute solo (BMV 1013) which Bach composed at the time when he worked at Koetchen Court, and is undoubtedly one of the best period of his life. This is coincident with the Suites for solo cello and with the Sonatas and Partitas for solo violin which represent the highest example of "stile concitato".

Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach, Sonata in F major for solo cello: this is the transcription for cello of the Sonata for flute and harpsichord in C major, a virtuosic flute masterpiece, for the first time performed by cello .

Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach, Sonata in D minor for solo cello: this transcription of the Sonata in A minor for solo flute represents one of the best examples of unaccompanied sonatas.

Heinrich Franz Ignaz Biber, Passacaglia in C minor for solo cello: this is the last of a series of sonatas Biber composed for solo violin (here transcribed for cello), each of them corresponds to one of the Mysteries of the Rosary. The Passacaglia had its origins in a Spanish dance (from the Spanish pasar, to walk, and calle, street; which means to go beyond the limits) and it consists of a series of continuous variations over a bass, with a strong hypnotic power.

Vito Paternoster, La Monica: this is a medieval-inspired passacaglia as well, with a set of continuous variations, increasingly arduous and polyphonic.

Vito Paternoster, The Spiritual Combat: inspired by the 17th-century homonymous Lorenzo Scupoli's bestseller (it was diffused more than the Bible and became soon a model of living and spiritual education during the Counter-Reformation), this suite starts maintaining a single note (D, that's RE in Italian, a polysemic word meaning also King) representing the Oneness around which a series of themes revolves, both rhythmically and melodically, in order to represent the fickle World.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Vito Paternoster/Solo cello works by JS Bach, CPE Bach, Biber and Paternoster/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Vito Paternoster/Solo cello works by JS Bach, CPE Bach, Biber and Paternoster/cover_200.jpg

name: CD1-Bach Cello Suites
description: Ah, no one does the bittersweet elegance of Bach like internatinoally acclaimed cellist Vito Paternoster. We love his stripped down, soulful approach to the six Bach cello suites; it really brings out their autumnal quality, and makes them everything they should be-full of both light and shadow, sorrow and joy. A wonderful, timeless recording that you'll find yourself reaching for again and again.

name: CD2-Bach Cello Suites
description: Ah, no one does the bittersweet elegance of Bach like internatinoally acclaimed cellist Vito Paternoster. We love his stripped down, soulful approach to the six Bach cello suites; it really brings out their autumnal quality, and makes them everything they should be-full of both light and shadow, sorrow and joy. A wonderful, timeless recording that you'll find yourself reaching for again and again.

name: Concerti and Serenate for cello
description:
Robert Schumann : "Unperformable" the cellist Robert Bockmuehl commented after the rehearsal on March the 23th 1851. Unfortunately, his commentary had a negative influence on record labels Schumann was dealing with: they then rejected every proposal, even the most profitable. Eventually, in November 1853 at Lipsia, the music publisher Breitkopf offered him a deal on condition that his piece should be suitable for public performance. Thence, Schumann thought of transcribing his piece both for violin (as his friend, the violinist Joseph Joachim suggested him) and for cello and string quartet. The orchestral adaptation was completed in 1854 and it was first performed by the orchestra in Moscow 1867 (cello by David Popper). Until then, the orchestral version was just played by the piano or by the string quartet. The present world premiere recording intends both to reproduce the poetics of music composed at that time and to recreate the mood inspired by the Concerto when it was being played between 1850 and 1867 .

Rossini : A young lady, a contender's fiancee, hopes her lover could win the great race; anxiety overtakes her until the victory joy. This instrumental transcription enhanced the melodic inventiveness of these emotional songs.

Mercadante : The Neapolitan composer wrote his last work when he was already blind. It was dedicated to a friend of his from Capri, a great cello lover.

Niccolo Paganini : Paganini's Variations for the fourth string on the theme from "Mose" by Rossini were conceived to be played on one string. It is said that Paganini would, on occasion, intentionally break strings himself during a performance so he could further display his virtuosity. Success was assured.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Vito Paternoster/Concerti and Serenate for cello/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Vito Paternoster/Concerti and Serenate for cello/cover_200.jpg

name: Vito Paternoster plays Haydn & Boccherini
description:
These famous cello concertos are played here for cello solo and bass without orchestra, in a world premiere recording of these works with this instrumentation. Renowned cellist Vito Paternoster discovered a manuscript dating back to the early nineteenth century, where a cellist realizes for cello and bass a transcription of the famous concerto in C major by Haydn.

Paternoster reminds us that Boccherini himself used to transcribe his sonatas in the form of concertos and vice versa.

Paternoster uses these manuscripts and this procedure, offering us the original transcriptions of the famous four Concertos, where the beauty of Haydn's music is sincerely enjoyable through the wonderful sounds of his cello and the joyfulness of his virtuosity.
cover: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Vito Paternoster/Vito Paternoster plays Haydn & Boccherini/cover_400.jpg
cover_small: http://he3.magnatune.com/music/Vito Paternoster/Vito Paternoster plays Haydn & Boccherini/cover_200.jpg

name: Inzaffirio
description: Oh how we love the echoing, haunting beauty of Italian cellist Vito Paternoster's Inzaffirio, a distillation of the preludes from Bach's Cello Suites. Following each prelude is an arrangement for solo cello, voice, and string orchestra.
